Ryanair's Spanish Pilots Agree to 20% Pay Cuts to Save Jobs
Ryanair's Spanish Pilots Agree to 20% Pay Cuts to Save Jobs
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
August 21, 2020 Friday 00:12
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 85 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYA.L) said Thursday its Spanish pilots accepted a four-year deal that includes 20% pay cuts to 
limit the number of job losses during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The agreement with Spanish pilot union SEPLA also comprises productivity improvements on rosters, flexible 
working patterns and annual leave.
The Irish budget airline, however, failed to reach deals with Spanish cabin crew unions USO and SITCPLA.
Ryanair fell 3% on Thursday's close.
Price (GBP): £11.13, Change: £-0.36, Percent Change: -3.18%
Load-Date: August 21, 2020
End of Document

Ryanair's Spanish pilots accept pay cuts to limit job losses
Ryanair's Spanish pilots accept pay cuts to limit job losses
Business World (Digest)
August 20, 2020 Thursday
Copyright 2020 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 234 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair's Spanish pilots accepted on Thursday a 20% pay cut and work practice changes, the latest deal the Irish 
airline has struck with trade unions in exchange for a pledge to minimize job losses.
Europe's biggest budget airline warned it would have to cut up to 3,000 jobs if it could not agree pay cuts with pilots 
and cabin crew after the COVID-19 crisis grounded 99% of its planes from April to June and continued to hit 
business thereafter.
Ryanair had reached agreements with 85% of its pilots and 75% of cabin crew by the end of July, including in other 
major markets such as Britain, Ireland and Germany.
However, it said on Thursday it had failed to strike a deal with Spanish cabin crew unions USO and SITCPLA, 
making job losses among their members more likely.
Ryanair this week reduced its capacity by a further 20% during September and October after a reimposition of 
some travel restrictions led to weak bookings.
Criticizing Ireland's strict restrictions that allow unencumbered travel to and from just 10 European countries, 
Ryanair Group Chief Executive Michael O'Leary warned on Wednesday of more jobs losses in its Irish operations.
While bookings were continuing to build in Germany, Italy and most other European countries, they were "terrible" 
in Ireland and certainly down 50% year-on-year, O'Leary told Irish national broadcaster RTE in an interview. 
(Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Ryanair's Spanish pilots accept pay cuts to limit job losses
Load-Date: September 15, 2020
End of Document
Wizz Air to open London Gatwick base in 4Q20
Wizz Air to open London Gatwick base in 4Q20
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
August 20, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 273 words
Body
Wizz Air (W6, Budapest) has announced that its British subsidiary Wizz Air UK (W9, London Luton) will open a new 
base at London Gatwick airport on October 22, 2020, with a single A321-200 stationed at the airport. The low-cost 
carrier will launch routes from Gatwick to Malta Int'l, Lanzarote (3x weekly each), Athens Int'l, and Naples 
Capodichino (4x weekly each). Gatwick will be its third base in the United Kingdom and second in the capital, after 
London Luton and the recently announced Doncaster/Sheffield base (which is also due to open on October 22, 
2020). Wizz Air currently serves Gatwick from its existing bases at Bucharest Otopeni, Budapest, Cluj-Napoca, 
Gdansk, Kraków, and Sofia, the ch-aviation schedules module shows. According to the ch-aviation fleets advanced 
module, Wizz Air UK operates three A320-200s and seven A321-200s. London Gatwick is the largest base of rival 
LCC easyJet (U2, London Luton). The airport is also a hub for British Airways (BA, London Heathrow), although the 
carrier's commitment to Gatwick is uncertain in the long-term, and for Norwegian Group carriers. 
Ryanair (FR, Dublin Int'l) does not have a base at Gatwick and maintains a relatively limited presence at the airport 
with a 3.3% market share by capacity in the week starting on August 24.

TimesSquare Capital Management LLC Sells 186,300 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
TimesSquare Capital Management LLC Sells 186,300 Shares of Ryanair 
Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
August 20, 2020 Thursday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 780 words
Body
Ryanair logo TimesSquare Capital Management LLC lowered its stake in  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) 
by 50.0% during the 2nd quarter, according to the company in its most recent disclosure with the Securities & 
Exchange Commission. The institutional investor  owned 186,100 shares of the transportation company's stock 
after selling 186,300 shares during the period. TimesSquare Capital Management LLC owned 0.08% of Ryanair 
worth $12,346,000 at the end of the most recent reporting period.  
Several other hedge funds have also made changes to their positions in the company. Capital Research Global 
Investors increased its holdings in  Ryanair by 430.1% during the 1st quarter. Capital Research Global Investors 
now owns 3,766,971 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $199,988,000 after purchasing an 
additional 3,056,407 shares during the period.  Polaris Capital Management LLC bought a new position in shares of  
Ryanair during the first quarter worth $74,459,000.  Baillie Gifford & Co. boosted its position in shares of  Ryanair 
by 10.8% during the first quarter. Baillie Gifford & Co. now owns 7,530,081 shares of the transportation company's 
stock worth $399,771,000 after purchasing an additional 732,578 shares in the last quarter.  Immersion Capital LLP 
raised its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 26.6% during the first quarter. Immersion Capital LLP now owns 
2,182,341 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $115,860,000 after acquiring an additional 458,047 
shares during the period.  Finally, Invesco Ltd. raised its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 28.0% during the first 
quarter. Invesco Ltd. now owns 1,589,509 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $84,387,000 after 
acquiring an additional 347,317 shares during the period. Hedge funds and other institutional investors own  
43.80% of the company's stock.  
NASDAQ RYAAY  traded down $1.64 on Thursday, reaching $76.09. 910 shares of the company were exchanged, 
compared to its average volume of 582,689. The business's fifty day moving average price is $72.70 and its 200 
day moving average price is $68.92. The stock has a market capitalization of $17.54 billion, a P/E ratio of 68.95 and 
a beta of 1.35. The company has a current ratio of 0.67, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60. 
Ryanair Holdings plc has a fifty-two week low of $44.44 and a fifty-two week high of $96.79.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 27th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.94) EPS for the quarter, beating the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of ($1.15) by 
$0.21. The business had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $138.60 
million. Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%.  Equities research analysts forecast 
that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post -3.75 earnings per share for the current year.  
TimesSquare Capital Management LLC Sells 186,300 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
A number of equities research analysts recently commented on RYAAY shares. Morgan Stanley  restated an 
"overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Tuesday, July 28th. UBS Group  restated a "buy" rating on 
shares of Ryanair in a report on Wednesday, May 20th. Credit Suisse Group  restated an "outperform" rating on 
shares of Ryanair in a report on Tuesday, July 28th. Zacks Investment Research  upgraded shares of Ryanair from 
a "strong sell" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $68.00 price objective on the stock in a report on Tuesday, May 
26th. Finally, JPMorgan Chase & Co. upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to an "overweight" rating in 
a research note on Monday, July 13th. Four equities research analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating, 
thirteen have issued  a buy rating and one  has given a strong buy rating to the company's stock. The stock 
currently has an average rating of "Buy" and a consensus target price of $79.00. 
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

The day in the markets What you need to know
The day in the markets; What you need to know
Financial Times (London, England)
August 20, 2020 Thursday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 9
Length: 418 words
Body
? US stocks climb to another intraday peak ? Pound strengthens ahead of renewed Brexit negotiations ? Gold's 
volatile run continues with the precious metal sinking 2% Global stocks edged higher yesterday a day after Wall 
Street climbed to its first record close since the pandemic roiled markets in February.
The S&P 500 hit a fresh intraday high at lunchtime in New York, climbing 0.2 per cent, with technology the best 
performing sector.
The peak in US stocks comes despite "historic social and economic upheaval", said Seema Shah, chief strategist at 
Principal Global Investors, meaning investors were "right to be cautious".
Wall Street's rapid rebound comes against a backdrop of persistently high Covid-19 cases. Coronavirus deaths in 
the US rose by more than 1,000 for the first time in three days on Tuesday.
Wall Street's rally also owes much to a "handful of companies", added Ms Shah. The five largest stocks in the S&P 
500 account for a quarter of the benchmark's advance since a sell-off in late March.
Across the Atlantic, the region-wide Stoxx Europe 600 closed up 0.7 per cent with bruised travel companies 
rebounding after Heathrow announced an on-site Covid-19 testing facility in an effort to cut quarantine times. The 
airport was, however, awaiting government approval for the scheme.
Airlines Ryanair and easyJet rallied while British Airways parent company IAG climbed more than 7 per cent.
The day in the markets What you need to know
Elsewhere in Europe, the pound approached its strongest level against the dollar this year, hitting a high of 
$1.3267, "although much of that is dollar related", said Derek Halpenny, head of Global Markets research at MUFG 
Bank, pointing to the weakness in the US currency. Sterling later pared back earlier gains to settle at $1.316.
Analysts at ING have characterised some traders as being "over complacent" when it comes to the pound.
"Sterling's recent good performance and resilience to grim economic data has likely relied on the Brexit story being 
put on the backburner by investors," said the Dutch bank, but "that could be about to change as negotiations 
restart".
Talks between London and Brussels resumed yesterday.
The possibility for the Bank of England adopting negative interest rates also weighed on the pound, said Mr 
Halpenny.
Government bonds were littlechanged, with the yield on the 10-year US Treasury slipping 1 basis point to 0.66 per 
cent, but gold's volatile run continued with the metal sinking more than 2 per cent to $1,9600 an ounce after several 
large swings last week. Ray Douglas
Load-Date: August 19, 2020
End of Document

UBS Group Reaffirms Buy Rating for Ryanair (LON:RYA)
UBS Group Reaffirms Buy Rating for Ryanair (LON:RYA)
Newstex Blogs 
Transcript Daily
August 20, 2020 Thursday 7:06 AM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 323 words
Body
Aug 
20, 
2020( 
Transcript 
Daily: 
https://transcriptdaily.com 
Delivered 
by 
Newstex)  
https://www.marketbeat.com/logos/ryanair-holdings-plc-logo.pngUBS Group reaffirmed their buy rating on shares of 
Ryanair (LON:RYA) in a report published on Monday morning, Borsen Zeitung[1] reports.Other equities analysts 
have also issued reports about the company. 
Morgan Stanley reissued a buy rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Wednesday, May 27th. Liberum Capital 
reiterated an under review rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Monday, July 27th. One research 
analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating and three have assigned a buy rating to the stock. The stock presently 
has an average rating of Buy and an average target price of GBX 13 ($0.17).Shares of Ryanair stock[2] opened at 
GBX 11.24 ($0.15) on Monday. The firm has a market cap of $122.47 million and a P/E ratio of 56.46. The business 
has a 50-day moving average price of GBX 11.09 and a 200 day moving average price of GBX 76.07. Ryanair has 
a fifty-two week low of GBX 8.05 ($0.11) and a fifty-two week high of GBX 16.97 ($0.22). The company has a quick 
ratio of 0.60, a current ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 103.04. About RyanairRyanair Holdings plc, 
together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and 
Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as non-
flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and 
marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.Featured Story:

Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Earning Very Negative Press Coverage, Report Shows
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Earning Very Negative Press Coverage, Report 
Shows
American Banking and Market News
August 19, 2020 Wednesday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 659 words
Body
Ryanair logo News headlines about Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have trended very negative recently, according to 
InfoTrie Sentiment. InfoTrie identifies positive and negative media coverage by monitoring more than six thousand 
news and blog sources in real-time. The firm ranks coverage of public companies on a scale of negative five to five, 
with scores nearest to five being the most favorable. Ryanair earned a media sentiment score of -3.80 on their 
scale. InfoTrie also assigned news articles about the transportation company an news buzz score of 0 out of 10, 
meaning that recent media coverage is extremely unlikely to have an impact on the stock's share price in the next 
few days.  
These are some of the news stories that may have impacted Ryanair's analysis: 
•
Ryanair to Slash Capacity by a Further 20% After Second Wave Fears Lead to Weak Demand - Paddle 
Your Own Kanoo  (paddleyourownkanoo.com)
•
The countries Ryanair is set to cancel flights to including Spain - Liverpool Echo  (liverpoolecho.co.uk)
•
Ryanair to cut September and October capacity by 20% - TTG  (ttgmedia.com)
•
Ryanair cancels 20% of flights amid COVID-19 restrictions - Business Insurance  (businessinsurance.com)
•
Ryanair Cuts 20 Percent of Autumn Flights Amid New Quarantine Rules - AviationPros.com  
(aviationpros.com)
NASDAQ:RYAAY  traded up $0.98 during trading hours on Wednesday, reaching $78.89. The stock had a trading 
volume of 1,746 shares, compared to its average volume of 591,960. Ryanair has a 12-month low of $44.44 and a 
12-month high of $96.79. The stock has a 50 day simple moving average of $72.44 and a 200 day simple moving 
average of $68.97. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a current ratio of 0.67. 
The stock has a market cap of $17.04 billion, a P/E ratio of 69.81 and a beta of 1.35.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 27th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.94) earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating the Thomson Reuters' consensus 
estimate of ($1.15) by $0.21. Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%. The company 
had revenue of $137.83 million during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $138.60 million.  On average, 
equities analysts expect that  Ryanair will post -3.74 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  
A number of analysts recently commented on the company. Raymond James increased their price target on 
Ryanair from $68.00 to $90.00 and gave the company a "strong-buy" rating in a research report on Thursday, July 
Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Earning Very Negative Press Coverage, Report Shows
30th. Zacks Investment Research  raised Ryanair from a "strong sell" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $68.00 price 
target for the company in a research report on Tuesday, May 26th. UBS Group  reaffirmed a "buy" rating on shares 
of Ryanair in a research report on Wednesday, May 20th. Barclays  reaffirmed an "overweight" rating on shares of 
Ryanair in a research report on Friday, August 14th. Finally, BidaskClub raised Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a 
"buy" rating in a research report on Thursday, August 13th. Four equities research analysts have rated the stock 
with a hold rating, thirteen have given a buy rating and one  has issued  a strong buy rating to the company. The 
company presently has an average rating of "Buy" and a consensus target price of $79.00. 
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Travelers Ebb But China, US Expand Flights: Airlines in Focus
Travelers Ebb But China, US Expand Flights: Airlines in Focus
Newstex Blogs 
Zacks Investment Research
August 19, 2020 Wednesday 3:51 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1293 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Aug 19, 2020( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Per a recent Airlines for 
America (A4A) study, the number of air travelers being screened by the Transportation Security Administration 
(TSA) plummeted nationally. On average, there has been a 50% reduction in flight departures with states like New 
York, Hawaii, Washington DC, Vermont, Massachusetts and New Jersey reporting more than 80% decline in the 
TSA checkpoint volumes. Low Traffic The latest total traveler throughput as of Aug 17 was 773,319. Prior to the 
ongoing global health crisis, U.S. airlines were transporting a record 2.5 million passengers and 58,000 tons of 
cargo each day. As travel constraints and stay-at-home orders were implemented, demand for air travel dropped 
sharply. 
In short, the estimated COVID-19-triggered loss outbreak is at least more than $98 billion in the first half of 
2020.Majority of the airline stocks have depreciated over the past week, causing the NYSE ARCA Airline Index to 
decline 5.6% to $55.94, showing that the coronavirus pandemic took a heavy toll on the airline industry.A4A further 
noted that the industry has a long road to recovery ahead. Air travel took three years to rebound from the 9/11 terror 
attacks and more than seven years to see a revival from the Global Financial Crisis of 2008. Market pundits believe 
that it may take at least two years or longer this time for the aviation industry to bounce back to its pre-COVID 
levels.Additionally, the spike in the cases of COVID-19 infection in some European countries will further foil 
passengers' travel plans. Earlier during the week, Germany joined the U.K. in imposing a two-week quarantine on 
flyers returning from Spain.Revenue declines and losses forced some airliners to suspend their dividend payouts 
and seek a relief under bankruptcy protection code. Companies like Alaska Air and Ryanair will be trimming 
respective capacities due to lower forward bookings. Increase in US-China Flight Frequency However, the news by 
The U.S. Transportation Department that U.S. and China agreed to double the number of airline flights between the 
two countries to eight per week bodes well for the concerned industry. Prior to the COVID-19 outbreak, there were 
more than 300 flights a week between the two countries. But the flight frequency took a hit as demand for 
international air travel dried up.It was announced that United Airlines (UAL) will increase flight services to China to 
four flights per week from San Francisco to Shanghai beginning Sep 4 while Delta Air Lines (DAL) will expand to 
four weekly flights. The deal marks a further easing of a standoff between the world's two biggest economies over 
the pandemic-led travel bans. Government Aid Also, another financial stimulus from the Congress augurs well for 
the airline industry. Possibility of a second airline bailout package strengthened after President Donald Trump 
backed the proposed extension of the Payroll Support Program under the Cares Act. In fact, a group of 16 
Travelers Ebb But China, US Expand Flights: Airlines in Focus
Republicans signed a recently, pleading for another financial relief.Moreover, travel stocks will get a boost as the 
State Department removed the warning on U.S. citizens against traveling abroad Airline Stocks in Focus Though 
travel will remain under pressure, the surge in flight operations to and from China, government grants and a gradual 
resurgence in travel demand put the airline industry on investors' radar to set sights on.Hence we shortlist a few 
stocks, each of which currently carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). You can see the complete list of today's Zacks #1 
Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here[1].Allegiant Travel Company ALGT[2] operates low-cost passenger carriers. It 
focuses on linking leisure travelers in small and medium-sized cities to world-class destinations.Though Allegiant 
Travel had an impressive record of dividend payments and share repurchases, it suspended the same following the 
coronavirus threat. The company's efforts to modernize its fleet look impressive, which drive its fuel efficiency in the 
process.I's earnings growth rate for the past five-year period is 12%. Its expected earnings growth rate for the next 
five-year period is 20.9%, higher than the industry average of 10.8%.Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[3] is an ultra-low 
fare carrier, offering scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the UK, Continental Europe, Morocco and 
Israel. Following months of fleet groundings amid coronavirus concerns, Ryanair resumed operations across 90% 
of its routes in July. Flying schedules are expected to gradually rise to 60% in August and 70% in September. The 
company's cost-cutting measures to combat coronavirus-related adversities are also encouraging.Its earnings 
growth rate for the past five-year period is 3%. Its expected earnings growth rate for the next five-year period is 
24%, higher than the industry average of 10.8%.Copa Holdings' CPA[4] cost-reduction efforts augur well. The 
airline anticipates to reduce its monthly cash burn to approximately $66 million in the second half of 2020 from $77 
million in the second quarter of 2020.The company is undergoing a fleet upgrade, which will improve its operating 
efficiency.Its expected earnings growth rate for the next five-year period is 13.6%, higher than the industry average 
of 10.8%. Breakout Biotech Stocks with Triple-Digit Profit Potential The biotech sector is projected to surge beyond 
$775 billion by 2024 as scientists develop treatments for thousands of diseases. They're also finding ways to edit 
the human genome to literally erase our vulnerability to these diseases.Zacks has just released Century of Biology: 
7 Biotech Stocks to Buy Right Now to help investors profit from 7 stocks poised for outperformance. Our recent 
biotech recommendations have produced gains of +50%, +83% and +164% in as little as 2 months. The stocks in 
this report could perform even better.See these 7 breakthrough stocks now > >[5]Want the latest recommendations

European ADRs Edge Lower in Tuesday Trading
European ADRs Edge Lower in Tuesday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
August 18, 2020 Tuesday 11:06 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 223 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.19% lower at 936.87 on the BNY Mellon Europe 
Select ADR Index on Tuesday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical companies Cellectis (CLLS) and DBV 
Technologies (DBVT), which rose 2.9% and 1.7% respectively. They were followed by brewing company Anheuser-
Busch InBev (BUD) and pharmaceutical firm Sanofi (SNY), which were up 1.6% and 1.1%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by biopharmaceutical company Biofrontera (BFRA) and 3D printer 
maker voxeljet (VJET), which fell 13% and 4.6% respectively. They were followed by biotech firm BioNTech (BNTX) 
and computer peripheral and software maker Logitech International (LOGI), which dropped 3.9% and 2.2%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical company Verona Pharma (VRNA) and airline 
operator Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY), which rose 2.2% and 2% respectively. They were followed by Lloyds Banking 
Group (LYG) and alcoholic beverage company Diageo (DEO), which were up 1.8% and 1.4%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by biopharmaceutical companies Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP) 
and MorphoSys (MOR), which lost 2.9% and 2.5% respectively. They were followed by educational publisher 
Pearson (PSO) and mining company BHP Group (BBL), which were down 2% and 1.9%.

easyJet to shutter three UK bases in late 3Q20
easyJet to shutter three UK bases in late 3Q20
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
August 18, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 333 words
Body
easyJet (U2, London Luton) has confirmed the closure of bases at each of London Stansted, London Southend, 
and Newcastle, GB effective August 31 as the budget airline consolidates its headcount amid depressed COVID-19 
travel demand. In a statement, the UK-headquartered LCC said London Stansted and Newcastle would remain part 
of its route network, and some domestic and international flights will continue to operate, served by inbound flying 
from other bases across its network. "During the consultation, we have identified ways to reduce the numbers of 
proposed compulsory redundancies across the business as a whole by offering enhanced voluntary redundancy 
packages to all UK crew as well as looking at additional options like part time and seasonal contracts, base 
transfers where possible and unpaid leave," it said. 
"As a result the number of compulsory redundancies will be significantly reduced, for example, through the 
consultation process with Unite 93% of our cabin crew who were at risk of redundancy have opted for an enhanced 
voluntary redundancy package." Through its easyJet UK (U2, London Luton) subsidiary, easyJet's other UK bases 
include Belfast Int'l, Bristol Int'l, Edinburgh, Glasgow Int'l, Liverpool, London Gatwick, London Luton, and 
Manchester Int'l. According to the ch-aviation capacities module, for the current week i.e. August 17-23, easyJet 
accounts for 5.98% of the 196,655 seats on offer at London Stansted (i.e. fourth behind Ryanair, Malta Air, and 
Jet2), 38.18% of the 13,641 seats on offer at London Southend (i.e. second behind Ryanair), and 22.89% of the 
29,853 seats on offer at Newcastle (second behind Jet2).

by 5.0% in the 2nd quarter, according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities & Exchange 
Commission. The fund owned 472,061 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 24,799 shares 
during the period. Thornburg Investment Management Inc. owned approximately 0.21% of Ryanair worth 
$31,317,000 at the end of the most recent reporting period.

Group Inc. boosted its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 23.5% in the second quarter. PNC Financial Services Group

institutional investors and hedge funds.

rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Tuesday, July 28th. Raymond James lifted their target price on shares of 
Ryanair from $68.00 to $90.00 and gave the stock a "strong-buy" rating in a research note on Thursday, July 30th.

"overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Tuesday, July 28th. Finally, Barclays  reiterated an 
"overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Friday. Four equities research analysts have rated 
the stock with a hold rating, thirteen have assigned  a buy rating and one  has given a strong buy rating to the 
company's stock. The company currently has an average rating of "Buy" and a consensus price target of $79.00.

Thornburg Investment Management Inc. Sells 24,799 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 27th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.94) earnings per share for the quarter, beating the consensus estimate of ($1.15) by $0.21. 
The firm had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $138.60 million. 
Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%.  As a group, equities research analysts 
expect that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post -3.74 earnings per share for the current year.  
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website. 
See Also: Limitations of analyzing profit margin 
Institutional Ownership by Quarter for Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) 
Load-Date: August 18, 2020
End of Document
Russell Investments Group Ltd. Purchases 94,467 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Russell Investments Group Ltd. Purchases 94,467 Shares of Ryanair 
Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
August 18, 2020 Tuesday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 700 words
Body
Ryanair logo Russell Investments Group Ltd. raised its position in  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 
100.8% in the 2nd quarter, according to the company in its most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange 
Commission (SEC). The firm owned 188,176 shares of the transportation company's stock after purchasing an 
additional 94,467 shares during the period. Russell Investments Group Ltd. owned 0.08% of Ryanair worth 
$12,528,000 at the end of the most recent reporting period.  
A number of other large investors have also recently made changes to their positions in RYAAY. Altium Wealth 
Management LLC bought a new position in  Ryanair in the 1st quarter valued at $230,000.  Envestnet Asset 
Management Inc. lifted its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 1.3% during the 1st quarter. Envestnet Asset 
Management Inc. now owns 59,235 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $3,145,000 after acquiring 
an additional 763 shares during the last quarter.  Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Holdings Inc. bought a new stake in shares 
of  Ryanair during the 1st quarter worth $1,003,000.  BBVA USA Bancshares Inc. bought a new stake in shares of  
Ryanair during the 1st quarter worth $510,000.  Finally, Crossmark Global Holdings Inc. lifted its holdings in shares 
of  Ryanair by 5.2% during the 1st quarter. Crossmark Global Holdings Inc. now owns 9,111 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $484,000 after acquiring an additional 450 shares during the last quarter. 
43.80% of the stock is owned by hedge funds and other institutional investors.  
A number of analysts have recently issued reports on RYAAY shares. JPMorgan Chase & Co. raised shares of 
Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to an "overweight" rating in a report on Monday, July 13th. BidaskClub raised shares 
of Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on Thursday, August 13th. UBS Group  reaffirmed a 
"buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Wednesday, May 20th. Raymond James lifted their target price on 
shares of Ryanair from $68.00 to $90.00 and gave the stock a "strong-buy" rating in a research report on Thursday, 
July 30th. Finally, Morgan Stanley  reiterated an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on 
Tuesday, July 28th. Four analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating, thirteen have issued  a buy rating and 
one  has given a strong buy rating to the company's stock. Ryanair currently has an average rating of "Buy" and an 
average price target of $79.00. 
NASDAQ:RYAAY  opened at $75.71 on Tuesday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a one year low of $44.44 and a one 
year high of $96.79. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a current ratio of 0.67 and a quick ratio of 0.67. 
The company's 50-day simple moving average is $72.23 and its 200 day simple moving average is $69.03. The firm 
has a market capitalization of $18.55 billion, a P/E ratio of 67.00 and a beta of 1.35.  
Russell Investments Group Ltd. Purchases 94,467 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 27th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.94) EPS for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of ($1.15) by $0.21. Ryanair had a 
net margin of 3.61% and a return on equity of 10.45%. The business had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, 
compared to analyst estimates of $138.60 million.  On average, equities research analysts expect that  Ryanair 
Holdings plc will post -3.74 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

filings and insider trades for Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY).

What you need to know The day in the markets
What you need to know; The day in the markets
Financial Times (London, England)
August 18, 2020 Tuesday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 11
Length: 416 words
Body
? Europe's travel and leisure sector hit by return of coronavirus restrictions ? Rally in haven assets sends gold back 
towards $2,000 ? Central bank stimulus helps lift Chinese stocks Stocks drifted higher and haven assets rebounded 
against a backdrop of flareups in coronavirus cases across the globe. For the second consecutive session, stocks 
linked to tourism sank as outbreaks in Europe led to the reintroduction of quarantine measures, such as the closure 
of nightclubs in Spain and Italy.
Ryanair fell 6 per cent after the lowcost airline announced it was cutting flight capacity by a fifth during the next two 
months because of weak bookings.
Europe's travel and leisure sector, which is down more than a third this year, dipped 1.5 per cent yesterday, trailing 
the wider Stoxx Europe 600 benchmark, which rose 0.3 per cent.
Elsewhere in Europe, London's commodities-leaning FTSE 100 was up 0.6 per cent, with miners among the biggest 
gainers. Anglo-American and Fresnillo climbed 2.8 per cent and 2.3 per cent respectively.
Another miner that gained was Barrick Gold, which rallied after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed it 
had added the world's second-largest miner of gold to its holdings.
The precious metal rose yesterday during a modest rally in haven assets, climbing 2.4 per cent to $1,987 an ounce.
Core government bonds, another asset considered relatively safe, were also in demand. The yield in the 10-year 
US Treasury slid 4 basis points to 0.67 per cent.
What you need to know The day in the markets
Wall Street was hovering near its alltime high at lunchtime in New York, with tech companies that have fared well 
during the pandemic rising.
Investors in mainland China appeared to brush aside simmering geopolitical tensions, focusing instead on the 
Rmb700bn ($101bn) of liquidity that was pumped into the domestic financial system by the People's Bank of China.
The CSI 300 index of Shanghai- and Shenzhen-listed stocks climbed 2.4 per cent, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng 
was 0.7 per cent higher. Elsewhere in Asia, Tokyo's Topix closed down 0.8 per cent. This came as Japan reported 
a 7.8 per cent fall in second-quarter gross domestic product.
However, Miguel Chanco, senior Asia economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, expected Japan's growth 
"bounceback in the current quarter to the tune of 6 per cent", although the recovery would be "more gradual than 
the steepness of the downturn, due to the second Covid-19 wave [hanging] over domestic demand and the still-
uneven relaxation of restrictions globally". Ray Douglas
Load-Date: August 17, 2020
End of Document

haven assets rebounded against a backdrop of flareups in coronavirus cases across the globe. For the second 
consecutive session, stocks linked to tourism sank as outbreaks in Europe led to the reintroduction of quarantine 
measures, such as the closure of nightclubs in Spain and Italy.
Ryanair fell 6 per cent after the lowcost airline announced it was cutting flight capacity by a fifth during the next two

The day in the markets
Wall Street was hovering near its alltime high at lunchtime in New York, with tech companies that have fared well 
during the pandemic rising.
Investors in mainland China appeared to brush aside simmering geopolitical tensions, focusing instead on the 
Rmb700bn ($101bn) of liquidity that was pumped into the domestic financial system by the People's Bank of China.

was 0.7 per cent higher. Elsewhere in Asia, Tokyo's Topix closed down 0.8 per cent. This came as Japan reported 
a 7.8 per cent fall in second-quarter gross domestic product.

Tuesday Papers: Trump turns up the heat on Huawei
Tuesday Papers: Trump turns up the heat on Huawei
Citywire
August 18, 2020 Tuesday 3:04 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 809 words
Byline: Himanshu Singh
Highlight: And stock market floats tumble to 11-year low as private equity circles struggling firms.
Body
Top stories
•
The Times: The US government has tightened restrictions on Huawei in a bid to curb the Chinese group’s 
access to electronic components.
•
The Daily Telegraph: The number of floats in London has plunged to an eleven-year low as struggling firms 
seek support from private equity barons to survive the Covid meltdown.
•
Financial Times: Geely Auto profits sank by 43% in the first half as the pandemic pushed the ambitious 
Chinese carmaker to slash its sales target for the year.
•
Financial Times: Carlyle has instructed its employees to avoid public transport on their commute to work, 
as the private equity manager prepares to reopen its London office next month.
•
Financial Times: Sanofi has agreed to buy the San Francisco-based Principia Biopharma in a $3.4 billion 
deal in an attempt to shift focus to therapies for rarer diseases.
•
Financial Times: The A-level and GCSE results of students in England will revert to grades predicted by 
teachers after the government performed the latest in a string of policy U-turn.
Business and economics
•
The Daily Telegraph: Shoppers tentatively visited more retail parks and shopping centres last week as 
confidence to go out and spend gradually returned.
•
The Times: The state-backed British Business Bank has given banks extra time to grant state-backed 
loans to medium-sized and larger businesses in an extension of Covid-19 support packages for the private 
sector.
•
The Times: Lockdown helped to boost sales at Cranswick, the pork and poultry producer, by a quarter as 
Covid-19 forced the country to dine at home.
•
Financial Times: Marketplace loans have defied fears of mass delinquencies, with impairment rates rising 
only moderately even as unemployment has spiked.
•
The Times: The successful float of Curevac, a German biotechnology company developing a coronavirus 
vaccine, has delivered a big paper profit for Glaxosmithkline.
Tuesday Papers: Trump turns up the heat on Huawei
•
Financial Times: Retail trading app Robinhood has raised new equity that gives it a valuation of more than 
$11 billion, up by nearly one-third from a previous injection of funds a month ago.
•
The Guardian: Redundancies at theatre companies owned by the leading west end producer Cameron 
Mackintosh are set to total more than 850.
•
The Guardian: Ryanair is to cancel almost one in five flights scheduled for September and October owing 
to a drop in bookings.
•
The Daily Telegraph: The collapse of the short-term letting market – once fuelled by tourists using online 
lettings website Airbnb – is leading to a glut of new long-term rental properties which is dramatically driving 
down prices.
•
The Times: A long-running dispute between Costain and the Welsh government over a key road contract 
has prompted the construction company to delay publishing its half-year results.
•
Daily Mail: Cambridge life sciences firm Horizon Discovery Group has said a reduction in academic 
research work caused by the coronavirus pandemic has negatively impacted its earnings.
•
The Times: The chief executive of Hamleys, David Smith, is to step down only seven months after he was 
appointed to lead the 260-year-old toy retailer.
•
Daily Mail: B R Shetty stepped down from his role at Finablr with immediate effect yesterday, with no 
explanation given for his departure in a one-sentence statement to the stock market.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Japan tumbled further into recession in the three months to June as GDP plunged by 
7.8%.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Amazon is being investigated by German competition authorities over its decision to 
block sellers for allegedly inflating prices during the pandemic.
Share tips, comment and bids
•
The Times (Tempus share tips): HOLD Murray International Trust; HOLD Hargreaves Lansdown.
•
The Guardian: The drinks group Diageo has agreed to buy a gin brand co-owned by the Hollywood actor 
Ryan Reynolds in a deal worth up to $610 million.
•
The Guardian: Tata Motors has denied reports it plans to sell its stake in Jaguar Land Rover after a 
breakdown in talks with the UK government to secure a financial rescue package.
•
The Times: Camellia said that Horizon Farms, in which it has an 80% interest, had agreed to sell its 
property and a growing crop of pistachios and almonds to Maricopa Orchards.
•
The Times: British American Tobacco, the owner of Dunhill and Lucky Strike cigarettes, said that it was 
considering a sale-and-leaseback deal for its head office in Westminster to raise more than £250 million.
•
The Times: Andy Bell, a co-founder of AJ Bell, has sold nearly £8 million of shares in the online investment 
platform.
•
Financial Times: Tencent has taken a stake in French mobile games company Voodoo, as the Chinese 
internet group looks to step up its pace of investments in Europe.
•
Financial Times: American Express is purchasing the online lending platform Kabbage for an undisclosed 
sum, as the card issuer aims to expand its product offering for small businesses.

Ryanair cuts autumn flight capacity by 20% Airlines ; Bookings weaken as fresh curbs dash hopes of seasonal 
upturn
Ryanair cuts autumn flight capacity by 20%; Airlines ; Bookings weaken as 
fresh curbs dash hopes of seasonal upturn
Financial Times (London, England)
August 18, 2020 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; Pg. 10
Length: 448 words
Byline: PHILIP GEORGIADIS
Body
Ryanair has cut back its flight schedule for the coming months after Europe's largest low-cost carrier warned that 
bookings had "noticeably weakened" following the rise in virus cases across many parts of Europe.
The resurgence of the virus is deepening the crisis facing the travel industry, as new government restrictions dash 
hopes of a late-summer tourism revival.
"Forward bookings have notably weakened over the last 10 days, given uncertainty over recent Covid case rates in 
some EU countries," Ryanair said.
In response, the airline will reduce the number of passengers it carries by 20 per cent in September and October.
The cuts will focus on countries where outbreaks are worsening, including France and Spain, and will come mainly 
from flying fewer planes on its network rather than eliminating routes altogether.
Ryanair had previously indicated that it hoped to run 70 per cent of its normal schedule in September, more than 
some low-cost rivals, including easyJet.
Michael O'Leary, chief executive, has said that a second wave of Covid-19 infections in the autumn is his biggest 
worry, and the disruption to his airline's business has come even sooner than feared.
Ryanair cuts autumn flight capacity by 20% Airlines ; Bookings weaken as fresh curbs dash hopes of seasonal 
upturn
Last month he cautioned that further disruption could lead to more pay cuts and job losses, after the airline fell to a 
loss in the three months to the end of June. The carrier has said it plans to axe up to 3,000 jobs.
Analysts believe, however, that Ryan-air is well placed to ride out the storm facing the sector, given that it typically 
operates from lower-cost airports and its finances are in better shape than some rivals. The airline had more than 
(EURO)3.9bn in cash at the end of June.
Shares in Ryanair led European airlines lower following the news, falling nearly 5 per cent.
EasyJet yesterday confirmed that it would close three of its UK hubs as part of plans to cut its workforce by 30 per 
cent. The airline will close its bases but still fly a scaled-down schedule from London Stansted and Newcastle, and 
entirely pull out of London Southend, the Essex airport it helped put onto the map over the past decade.
EasyJet's chief executive said the government's quarantine measures had "compounded" the lack of demand for 
seats.
The disruption to air travel came as one of the leading cross-Channel ferry operators said it could cut the numbers 
of crossings it sails following the introduction of quarantine rules for anyone entering the UK from France.
The chief executive of Brittany Ferries, which operates 12 ships between France, the UK, Ireland and Spain, said 
he was facing "tough decisions" on which routes to run.
The focus will be on countries where outbreaks are worsening, including France and Spain
Load-Date: August 17, 2020
End of Document
Eurozone Shopping centre landlord Unibail-Rodamco-Westfield [...]
Eurozone Shopping centre landlord Unibail-Rodamco-Westfield [...]
Financial Times (London, England)
August 18, 2020 Tuesday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 11
Length: 215 words
Body
Eurozone Shopping centre landlord Unibail-Rodamco-Westfield faded in the wake of reports last week that it was 
considering raising up to (EURO)3bn with a rights issue. The company said it was continuing to examine "all 
potential strategies" for strengthening its financial profile, with no decision made yet.
Kempen & Co analysts estimated that Unibail would need between (EURO)6bn and (EURO)8bn of new equity over 
the next three to five years, on top of (EURO)6bn from disposals. A smaller cash call in the short term may ease 
some of the pressure on its balance sheet and encourage short sellers to reduce their bets, said the broker.
Castellum, the Swedish property group, retreated after UBS cut its rating to "sell". A survey found that 82 per cent 
of Swedes were happy working from home, against 71 per cent of Germans, UBS said.
Tourism and leisure stocks slipped after the Netherlands, Germany and Belgium followed the UK in broadening 
their travel restrictions. Ryanair was the weakest among the airlines after warning of slower demand and 
announcing capacity cuts for September and October.
Pernod Ricard gained after Barclays upgraded the beverage group to "overweight", saying demand for premium 
spirits was likely to remain relatively resilient through a global recession. Bryce Elder
Load-Date: August 17, 2020
Eurozone Shopping centre landlord Unibail-Rodamco-Westfield [...]
End of Document

the next three to five years, on top of (EURO)6bn from disposals. A smaller cash call in the short term may ease 
some of the pressure on its balance sheet and encourage short sellers to reduce their bets, said the broker.
Castellum, the Swedish property group, retreated after UBS cut its rating to "sell". A survey found that 82 per cent 
of Swedes were happy working from home, against 71 per cent of Germans, UBS said.
Tourism and leisure stocks slipped after the Netherlands, Germany and Belgium followed the UK in broadening 
their travel restrictions. Ryanair was the weakest among the airlines after warning of slower demand and 
announcing capacity cuts for September and October.
Pernod Ricard gained after Barclays upgraded the beverage group to "overweight", saying demand for premium 
spirits was likely to remain relatively resilient through a global recession. Bryce Elder
Load-Date: August 17, 2020

Aug 18, 2020( Zolmax.com: http://www.zolmax.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Russell Investments Group Ltd. raised 
its position in Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 100.8% in the 2nd quarter, according to the company in 
its most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The firm owned 188,176 shares of the 
transportation company's stock after purchasing an additional 94,467 shares during the period. Russell Investments 
Group Ltd. 
owned 0.08% of Ryanair worth $12,528,000 at the end of the most recent reporting period. A number of other large 
investors have also recently made changes to their positions in RYAAY. Altium Wealth Management LLC bought a 
new position in Ryanair in the 1st quarter valued at $230,000. Envestnet Asset Management Inc. lifted its holdings 
in shares of Ryanair by 1.3% during the 1st quarter. Envestnet Asset Management Inc. now owns 59,235 shares of 
the transportation company's stock worth $3,145,000 after acquiring an additional 763 shares during the last 
quarter. Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Holdings Inc. bought a new stake in shares of Ryanair during the 1st quarter worth 
$1,003,000. BBVA USA Bancshares Inc. bought a new stake in shares of Ryanair during the 1st quarter worth 
$510,000. Finally, Crossmark Global Holdings Inc. lifted its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 5.2% during the 1st 
quarter. Crossmark Global Holdings Inc. now owns 9,111 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$484,000 after acquiring an additional 450 shares during the last quarter. 43.80% of the stock is owned by hedge 
funds and other institutional investors. A number of analysts have recently issued reports on RYAAY shares. 
JPMorgan Chase &#38; Co. raised shares of Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to an "overweight" rating in a report on 
Monday, July 13th. BidaskClub raised shares of Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on 
Thursday, August 13th. UBS Group reaffirmed a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Wednesday, May 
20th. Raymond James lifted their target price on shares of Ryanair from $68.00 to $90.00 and gave the stock a 
"strong-buy" rating in a research report on Thursday, July 30th. Finally, Morgan Stanley reiterated an "overweight" 
rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Tuesday, July 28th. Four analysts have rated the stock with a 
hold rating, thirteen have issued a buy rating and one has given a strong buy rating to the company's stock. Ryanair 
currently has an average rating of "Buy" and an average price target of $79.00.NASDAQ:RYAAY[1] opened at 
$75.71 on Tuesday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a one year low of $44.44 and a one year high of $96.79. The 
company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a current ratio of 0.67 and a quick ratio of 0.67. The company's 50-day 
simple moving average is $72.23 and its 200 day simple moving average is $69.03. The firm has a market 
capitalization of $18.55 billion, a P/E ratio of 67.00 and a beta of 1.35. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its 
quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 27th. The transportation company reported ($0.94) EPS for the quarter, 
Russell Investments Group Ltd. Purchases 94,467 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
topping the consensus estimate of ($1.15) by $0.21. Ryanair had a net margin of 3.61% and a return on equity of 
10.45%. The business had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $138.60 
million. On average, equities research analysts expect that Ryanair Holdings plc will post -3.74 earnings per share 
for the current fiscal year. Ryanair Company ProfileRyanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides 
scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company 
is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-

Thornburg Investment Management Inc. Sells 24,799 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Thornburg Investment Management Inc. Sells 24,799 Shares of Ryanair 
Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
Newstex Blogs 
Week Herald
August 18, 2020 Tuesday 9:06 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 714 words
Body
Aug 18, 2020( Week Herald: https://weekherald.com Delivered by Newstex)  Thornburg Investment Management 
Inc. cut its holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 5.0% in the 2nd quarter, according to its most 
recent Form 13F filing with the Securities &#38; Exchange Commission. The fund owned 472,061 shares of the 
transportation company's stock after selling 24,799 shares during the period. 
Thornburg Investment Management Inc. owned approximately 0.21% of Ryanair worth $31,317,000 at the end of 
the most recent reporting period. A number of other institutional investors have also bought and sold shares of the 
business. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. boosted its stake in shares of Ryanair by 23.5% in the second 
quarter. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. now owns 958 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$64,000 after acquiring an additional 182 shares during the period. Harbor Investment Advisory LLC bought a new 
stake in shares of Ryanair in the 1st quarter valued at about $91,000. Tower Research Capital LLC TRC bought a 
new stake in shares of Ryanair in the 1st quarter valued at about $124,000. Vestmark Advisory Solutions Inc. 
bought a new stake in shares of Ryanair in the 1st quarter valued at about $200,000. Finally, Dynamic Technology 
Lab Private Ltd bought a new stake in shares of Ryanair in the 1st quarter valued at about $212,000. 43.80% of the 
stock is owned by institutional investors and hedge funds. RYAAY has been the topic of a number of recent analyst 
reports. Credit Suisse Group restated an "outperform" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Tuesday, July 28th. 
Raymond James lifted their target price on shares of Ryanair from $68.00 to $90.00 and gave the stock a "strong-
buy" rating in a research note on Thursday, July 30th. Zacks Investment Research[1] upgraded shares of Ryanair 
from a "strong sell" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $68.00 target price for the company in a research note on 
Tuesday, May 26th. Morgan Stanley reiterated an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on 
Tuesday, July 28th. Finally, Barclays reiterated an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on 
Friday. Four equities research analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating, thirteen have assigned a buy rating 
and one has given a strong buy rating to the company's stock. The company currently has an average rating of 
"Buy" and a consensus price target of $79.00.NASDAQ RYAAY[2] traded up $2.15 during mid-day trading on 
Tuesday, reaching $77.86. The stock had a trading volume of 9,033 shares, compared to its average volume of 
586,340. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1 year low of $44.44 and a 1 year high of $96.79. The stock has a market cap 
of $17.46 billion, a PE ratio of 68.73 and a beta of 1.35. The company has a fifty day moving average price of 
$72.23 and a 200 day moving average price of $69.03. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a current 
ratio of 0.67 and a quick ratio of 0.67. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly earnings results on 
Monday, July 27th. The transportation company reported ($0.94) earnings per share for the quarter, beating the 
Thornburg Investment Management Inc. Sells 24,799 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
consensus estimate of ($1.15) by $0.21. The firm had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to 
analysts' expectations of $138.60 million. Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%. As 
a group, equities research analysts expect that Ryanair Holdings plc will post -3.74 earnings per share for the 
current year. Ryanair Company ProfileRyanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-
passenger airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also 
involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related 
services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car 
hire, and travel insurance through its Website.See Also: Limitations of analyzing profit margin[3] [ 1]:

Airline Stock Roundup: AZUL 's Q2 Loss, ALK 's Bullish Cash-Burn Update & More
Airline Stock Roundup: AZUL's Q2 Loss, ALK's Bullish Cash-Burn Update & 
More
Newstex Blogs 
Zacks Investment Research
August 18, 2020 Tuesday 4:10 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1530 words
Byline: Maharathi Basu
Body
Aug 18, 2020( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  In the past week, Azul 
AZUL[1] reported a loss in second-quarter 2020 results. This underperformance was due to weak passenger 
revenues as a result of deteriorating air-travel demand, which emanated from the coronavirus pandemic. Notably, 
another Latin American carrier, Copa Holdings, CPA[2] also posted discouraging second-quarter earnings numbers 
in the previous week[3].On the non- earnings front, Alaska Air Group ALK[4] was the primary newsmaker, courtesy 
of its improved projection for August cash burn compared with July when ticket sales plummeted due to the 
renewed spike in coronavirus cases in the United States. Meanwhile, European carrier Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[5] 
trimmed its capacity for both September and October due to the pandemic-induced uncertainty following the rise in 
infected cases in some European countries. 
Recap of the Past Week's Top Stories 1. Azul incurred a loss of $2.38 per share (excluding $2.33 from non-
recurring items) in the second quarter of 2020, wider than the Zacks Consensus Estimate of a loss of $1.11. 
However, in the year-ago quarter, the company delivered adjusted earnings of 78 cents per share when air-travel 
demand was strong. Results were affected by the coronavirus-induced drop in demand and a 38% depreciation in 
the Brazilian Real. Also, total revenues of $74.9 million lagged the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $103.4 million and 
declined 88.9% year over year as well. Further, passenger revenues, accounting for bulk (70.3%) of the top line, 
plummeted 88.6% year over year amid low demand due to coronavirus. Revenues from cargo and other sources 
too decreased 8.5% in the quarter. Consolidated load factor (% of seats filled by passengers) contracted 11.3 
percentage points to 72.8% as the fall in traffic (85.2%) was deeper than the capacity contraction (82.9%) in the 
second quarter.While total revenues per ASK (RASK) dropped 10.3%, passenger revenues per ASK (PRASK) 
plunged 33.6%. Moreover, cost per ASK (CASK) surged in excess of 100%, mainly due to capacity cuts. However, 
fuel price per liter decreased 42% in the June quarter. Also, average fare for the company declined 13.4% from the 
year-ago quarter's figure.Azul exited the second quarter with a passenger operating fleet size of 138 jets. The 
average age of the fleet is 6 years. Contractual passenger fleet size was 165. The company expects to achieve 
roughly 60% of the pre-coronavirus capacity levels by December 2020. For the remainder of this year, Azul 
anticipates a daily cash burn of approximately R$3 million, on average.Azul currently carries a Zacks Rank #3 
(Hold). You can see the complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.[6]2. Alaska Air anticipates 
its revenues for August to decline in the 70-75% band on a year-over-year basis due to weak demand for air travel. 
Airline Stock Roundup: AZUL 's Q2 Loss, ALK 's Bullish Cash-Burn Update & More
Revenue passengers for August 2020 are also predicted to plunge between 70% and 75% from August 2019 
readings. To combat the bleak demand scenario, Alaska Air is slashing capacity (measured in available seat miles 
or ASMs). ASMs for August are projected to be down nearly 50% from the year-ago levels. Courtesy of higher ticket 
sales, cash burn is projected to improve to less than $125 million in the current month from approximately $175 
million reported last month[7].3. Ryanair will be reducing capacity by 20% for September as well as October due to 
lower forward bookings of late as coronavirus cases in some European countries show a surge. The cuts will be 
focused on countries where the spurt in COVID-19 cases resulted in increased travel restrictions by the UK and 
Ireland. Moreover, the capacity reduction will mostly be felt in the form of decreased flight frequency rather than 
route closures.4 United Airlines UAL[8] is planning to add up to 28 daily non-stop flights to Florida this winter as air-
travel demand seems to be picking up after months of slowdown. The airline intends to add flights from New York, 
NY, Boston, MA and Cleveland, OH to the Florida cities of Fort Lauderdale, Fort Myers, Orlando and Tampa, 
effective Nov 6[9].5. Per a CNBC report[10], American Airlines AAL[11] decided to cancel flights to up to 30 small 
and medium cities in the wake of the COVID-19 outbreak-led tepid demand for air travel. The plan to shrink 
services will, however, not materialize before October, 2020. This is because of the fact that per the federal 
assistance to U.S. carriers under the CARES Act, airlines receiving the aid are required to maintain a minimum 
level of service and not lay off any employee through Sep 30. Notably, American Airlines is granted $5.8 billion 
relief package under the scheme. Performance The following table shows the price movement of major airline 
players over the past week and during the past six months.The table above shows that all airline stocks have traded 
in the red over the past week, causing the NYSE ARCA Airline Index to decline 5.2% to $55.34 as coronavirus-
related woes relentlessly hurt the industry. Over the course of the past six months, the NYSE ARCA Airline Index 
has depreciated 50.2%. What's Next in the Airline Space? With the second-quarter 2020 earnings season being 
over for airlines, investors interested in the space will now await the carriers' updates on how to combat the 
coronavirus-induced dismal travel demand. Looking for Stocks with Skyrocketing Upside? Zacks has just released a 
Special Report on the booming investment opportunities of legal marijuana.Ignited by new referendums and 
legislation, this industry is expected to blast from an already robust $6.7 billion to $20.2 billion in 2021. Early 
investors stand to make a killing, but you have to be ready to act and know just where to look.See the pot trades 
we're 
targeting

Aug 18, 2020( TheOlympiaReport: https://theolympiareport.com Delivered by Newstex)  Thornburg Investment 
Management Inc. decreased its holdings in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 5.0% in the 2nd 
quarter, Holdings Channel[1] reports. The firm owned 472,061 shares of the transportation company's stock after 
selling 24,799 shares during the quarter. 
Thornburg Investment Management Inc.'s holdings in Ryanair were worth $31,317,000 as of its most recent filing 
with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). Other hedge funds have also added to or reduced their 
stakes in the company. Altium Wealth Management LLC bought a new stake in Ryanair during the 1st quarter 
valued at approximately $230,000. Envestnet Asset Management Inc. lifted its stake in shares of Ryanair by 1.3% 
during the first quarter. Envestnet Asset Management Inc. now owns 59,235 shares of the transportation company's 
stock valued at $3,145,000 after acquiring an additional 763 shares during the period. Sumitomo Mitsui Trust 
Holdings Inc. acquired a new position in shares of Ryanair during the first quarter valued at $1,003,000. BBVA USA 
Bancshares Inc. acquired a new position in shares of Ryanair during the first quarter valued at $510,000. Finally, 
Crossmark Global Holdings Inc. increased its holdings in Ryanair by 5.2% in the first quarter. Crossmark Global 
Holdings Inc. now owns 9,111 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $484,000 after purchasing an 
additional 450 shares during the last quarter. Hedge funds and other institutional investors own 43.80% of the 
company's stock. Shares of NASDAQ:RYAAY[2] traded up $2.15 during mid-day trading on Tuesday, reaching 
$77.86. 9,033 shares of the stock were exchanged, compared to its average volume of 586,340. The company has 
a quick ratio of 0.67, a current ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60. The company has a market cap of 
$17.46 billion, a P/E ratio of 68.73 and a beta of 1.35. Ryanair Holdings plc has a one year low of $44.44 and a one 
year high of $96.79. The stock's 50 day simple moving average is $72.23 and its 200-day simple moving average is 
$69.03. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 27th. The 
transportation company reported ($0.94) EPS for the quarter, beating the consensus estimate of ($1.15) by $0.21. 
Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%. The firm had revenue of $137.83 million 
during the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $138.60 million. Analysts anticipate that Ryanair Holdings 
plc will post -3.74 EPS for the current fiscal year. RYAAY has been the subject of a number of recent analyst 
reports. Barclays reiterated an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Friday. Zacks Investment 
Research[3] upgraded Ryanair from a "strong sell" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $68.00 price objective for the 
company in a report on Tuesday, May 26th. Raymond James increased their price target on Ryanair from $68.00 to 
$90.00 and gave the stock a "strong-buy" rating in a report on Thursday, July 30th. JPMorgan Chase &#38; Co. 
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Position Trimmed by Thornburg Investment Management Inc.
upgraded Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to an "overweight" rating in a report on Monday, July 13th. Finally, UBS 
Group restated a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Wednesday, May 20th. Four research analysts 
have rated the stock with a hold rating, thirteen have assigned a buy rating and one has given a strong buy rating to 
the company's stock. Ryanair presently has an average rating of "Buy" and an average price target of 
$79.00.Ryanair Company ProfileRyanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger 
airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the 
provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight 
sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel

Ryanair to Cut Capacity by 20% Due to Weakness in Bookings
Ryanair to Cut Capacity by 20% Due to Weakness in Bookings
Newstex Blogs 
Zacks Investment Research
August 18, 2020 Tuesday 1:20 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 842 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Aug 18, 2020( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Ryanair Holdings plc 
RYAAY[1] will be cutting capacity by 20% for September and October due to a drop in bookings lately as 
coronavirus cases in some European Union countries surge. Following this news, shares of the company dipped 
2.4% at the close of business on Aug 17.The cuts will be focused on flights to countries on which travel restrictions 
have been imposed by the United Kingdom and Ireland because of a surge in COVID-19 cases. Moreover, the 
capacity reduction would mostly be in the form of decreased frequency rather than route closures.Re-imposition of 
quarantine rules by United Kingdom and travel restrictions by Ireland have 'notably weakened' Ryanair's forward 
bookings over the last 10 days. The United Kingdom re-imposed quarantine rules on travelers coming from 
countries such as Spain, France and Sweden. Ireland's measures have been regarded as "uniquely restrictive" by 
the airline. Ryanair Holdings PLC Price https://www.zacks.com/stock/chart/RYAAY/price?icid=chart-RYAAY-
fundamental/price Ryanair Holdings PLC price[2] | Ryanair Holdings PLC Quote[3] It was only last month that the 
carrier resumed operations following months of fleet groundings amid coronavirus concerns. 
The airline is expected to have operated approximately 40% of its normal schedule in July. This Irish low-cost airline 
had planned to gradually increase flying schedules to 60% in August and 70% in September.Passengers affected 
as a result of the capacity cuts in the next two months would be informed of the alternative options they can avail.

Ryanair cuts flights as contagions increase
Ryanair cuts flights as contagions increase
Newstex Blogs 
New Europe
August 18, 2020 Tuesday 10:07 AM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 196 words
Byline: EP|NE
Body
Aug 18, 2020( New Europe: https://www.neweurope.eu/ Delivered by Newstex)  The Irish budget airline Ryanair on 
Monday announced plans to cut capacity by 20% in September and October following a drop in travel demand due 
to a new surge in COVID-19 infections across Europe. The company said in a statement that most of the cuts would 
come from trimming the frequency of flights, and would be focused on flights serving countries such as Spain, 
France and Sweden, which have seen a rise in coronavirus cases. Last month, the airline announced a loss of €185 
million[1] for the first quarter of 2020, which included an almost total grounding of air traffic due to the coronavirus 
pandemic. Ryanair also called on Ireland to ease restrictions on travel from countries where coronavirus infection 
rates are lower than in Ireland. Travelers from countries like Germany and the United Kingdom are obligated to 
quarantine[2] 
for 
14 
days, 
even 
though 
Ireland 
has 
a 
higher 
infection 
rate.
