Budget carrier Ryanair cuts flights as contagions increase
Budget carrier Ryanair cuts flights as contagions increase
Associated Press Financial Wire
August 17, 2020 Monday 5:28 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS; INTERNATIONAL NEWS
Length: 273 words
Dateline: LONDON 
Body
LONDON (AP) — Ryanair, Europe’s largest airline, plans to cut capacity by 20% in September and October as a 
surge in COVID-19 cases dents bookings.
The low-cost carrier said Monday that most of the reductions would come from trimming the frequency of flights, 
rather than route closures. Ryanair said the cuts would be focused on flights serving countries such as Spain, 
France and Sweden, where a rise in coronavirus cases has triggered tighter travel restrictions.
The airline said in a statement that the curbs were “unavoidable given the recent weakness in forward bookings due 
to COVID restrictions in a number of EU countries.’’ Affected passengers will receive emails advising them of their 
options.
Dublin-based Ryanair also called on Ireland to ease restrictions on travel from countries where COVID-19 infection 
rates are lower than in Ireland. Travelers from countries like Germany and the U.K. are required to quarantine for 
two weeks, even though Ireland has a higher infection rate.
Meanwhile, British rival easyJet said it would move ahead with plans to close its bases at Stansted, Southend and 
Newcastle airports in England after consulting with unions.
The airline said all flights to and from Southend would be cancelled beginning Sept. 1. EasyJet said it will continue 
to serve Stansted and Newcastle from other hubs, but some flights to and from the airports will be cancelled.
EasyJet said in June that 1,900 jobs were at risk, but consultations continue and the overall number is likely to be 
lower. Of those at risk positions, some 670 pilot and crew jobs are located at the three bases whose closure was 
confirmed Monday.
Load-Date: August 17, 2020
End of Document
European ADRs Move Higher in Monday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Monday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
August 17, 2020 Monday 11:06 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 228 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.91% higher at 940.67 on the BNY Mellon Europe 
Select ADR Index on Monday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical company Genfit (GNFT) and dating app operator 
Spark Networks (LOV), which rose 4.3% and 3.8% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical company 
Cellectis (CLLS) and biotech firm BioNTech (BNTX), which were up 3.4% and 3.3%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by biopharmaceutical company Biofrontera (BFRA) and 3D printer 
maker voxeljet (VJET), which fell 9.7% and 3.3% respectively. They were followed by insurance firm Trean 
Insurance Group, Inc. (TIG) and furniture maker Natuzzi (NTZ), which were down 1.6% and 1.3%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by mining company Barrick Gold Corporation (GOLD) and 
pharmaceutical firm Avadel Pharmaceuticals (AVDL), which climbed 11% and 8.7% respectively. They were 
followed by biopharmaceutical companies Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP) and Bicycle Therapeutics (BCYC), 
which rose 4.7% and 4.4%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by airplane lessor Fly Leasing Limited (FLY) and Trinity Biotech 
(TRIB), which lost 9.6% and 8.8% respectively. They were followed by cruise line operator Carnival Corporation 
(CUK) and airline operator Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY), which fell 4.8% and 3.8%.
Load-Date: August 18, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair cuts Sept & Oct capacity by 20% on weak bookings
Ryanair cuts Sept & Oct capacity by 20% on weak bookings
Business World (Digest)
August 17, 2020 Monday
Copyright 2020 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 222 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair will reduce its flight capacity by a further 20% during September and October after a reimposition of some 
travel restrictions led to a notable weakness in forward bookings over the last 10 days, the Irish airline said on 
Monday.
Ryanair, which last month cut its passenger target to 60 million for the financial year to March 2021, from the 80 
million it had forecast in May, said a recent upsurge of COVID-19 cases in some European countries had 
particularly impacted business bookings.
Ryanair shares, which had rallied in recent sessions to their highest since early June, fell 4.4% to 11.22 euros by 
1220 GMT.
The airline said cuts will be heavily focused on France, Spain Ireland and Sweden, and would mostly involve 
frequency reductions rather than route closures. It had increased flights to 60% of its normal schedule this month 
after resuming services in July.
Europe's biggest budget airline said last month it expected to run around 70% of last year's schedule between 
October and March.
Increased travel restrictions have hit air traffic to Spain and France in recent weeks, while Ireland only allows 
unencumbered travel to 10 European countries, a policy Ryanair criticized again as "uniquely restrictive" on 
Monday.
Ryanair said impacted passengers will be advised of their options. (Reuters)
Ryanair cuts Sept & Oct capacity by 20% on weak bookings
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: September 10, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Earns Overweight Rating from Barclays
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Earns Overweight Rating from Barclays
Newstex Blogs 
Watchlist News
August 17, 2020 Monday 10:30 AM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 944 words
Body
Aug 17, 2020( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) 
Earns Overweight Rating from Barclays August 17th, 2020 - Comments Off on Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Earns 
Overweight Rating from Barclays - Filed Under[1] - by Micah Haroldson[2]   
https://www.marketbeat.com/logos/ryanair-holdings-plc-logo.jpgBarclays[3] reaffirmed their overweight rating on 
shares of Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) in a report published on Friday. Several other equities research analysts also 
recently issued reports on the stock. UBS Group restated a buy rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on 
Wednesday, May 20th. BidaskClub raised Ryanair from a hold rating to a buy rating in a research report on 
Thursday. Raymond James raised their target price on Ryanair from $68.00 to $90.00 and gave the stock a strong-
buy rating in a research report on Thursday, July 30th. JPMorgan Chase &#38; Co. raised Ryanair from a neutral 
rating to an overweight rating in a research report on Monday, July 13th. Finally, Zacks Investment Research[4] 
raised Ryanair from a strong sell rating to a buy rating and set a $68.00 target price for the company in a research 
report on Tuesday, May 26th. Four analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating, thirteen have issued a buy 
rating and one has assigned a strong buy rating to the stock. Ryanair has a consensus rating of Buy and an 
average price target of $79.00. NASDAQ RYAAY[5] opened at $77.57 on Friday. Ryanair has a 52-week low of 
$44.44 and a 52-week high of $96.79. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a current ratio of 0.67 and a 
quick ratio of 0.67. The company has a 50 day simple moving average of $71.56 and a 200-day simple moving 
average of $69.19. The firm has a market capitalization of $18.55 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 68.65 and a 
beta of 1.35.   Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 27th. The 
transportation company reported ($0.94) earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate 
of ($1.15) by $0.21. The business had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to the consensus 
estimate of $138.60 million. Ryanair had a net margin of 3.61% and a return on equity of 10.45%. On average, 
analysts predict that Ryanair will post -3.74 EPS for the current year. Hedge funds and other institutional investors 
have recently modified their holdings of the business. Rockefeller Capital Management L.P. increased its stake in 
shares of Ryanair by 239.7% in the second quarter. Rockefeller Capital Management L.P. now owns 822 shares of 
the transportation company's stock valued at $55,000 after buying an additional 580 shares in the last quarter. PNC 
Financial Services Group Inc. increased its stake in shares of Ryanair by 23.5% in the second quarter. PNC 
Financial Services Group Inc. now owns 958 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $64,000 after 
buying an additional 182 shares in the last quarter. Harbor Investment Advisory LLC acquired a new stake in shares 
of Ryanair in the first quarter valued at $91,000. Tower Research Capital LLC TRC acquired a new stake in shares 
of Ryanair in the first quarter valued at $124,000. Finally, First Republic Investment Management Inc. acquired a 
Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Earns Overweight Rating from Barclays
new stake in shares of Ryanair in the second quarter valued at $231,000. 43.80% of the stock is owned by 
institutional investors.  About Ryanair Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-
passenger airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also 
involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related 
services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car 
hire, and travel insurance through its Website. See Also: What are Institutional Investors?[6]Receive News &#38;

research analysts at UBS Group in a research note issued to investors on Monday, Borsen Zeitung[3] reports. RYA 
has been the topic of several other research reports. Morgan Stanley reaffirmed a 'buy' rating on shares of Ryanair 
in a research report on Wednesday, May 27th. 
Liberum Capital reaffirmed an 'under review' rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Monday, July 27th.

stock. The stock has an average rating of 'Buy' and a consensus price target of GBX 13 ($0.17). Shares of Ryanair 
stock[4] opened at GBX 11.56 ($0.15) on Monday. The stock's fifty day moving average is GBX 10.98 and its two-
hundred day moving average is GBX 76.16. The company has a market capitalization of $125.96 million and a PE 
ratio of 58.07. The company has a quick ratio of 0.60, a current ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 103.04.

Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved

Ryanair logo Ryanair (LON:RYA)'s stock had its "buy" rating reissued by equities research analysts at UBS Group 
in a report issued on Monday, Borsen Zeitung  reports. 
Several other equities research analysts have also issued reports on RYA. Liberum Capital  reissued an "under 
review" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Monday, July 27th. Morgan Stanley  reaffirmed a "buy" 
rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Wednesday, May 27th. One investment analyst  has rated the 
stock with a sell rating and three have issued  a buy rating to the company. The stock presently has a consensus 
rating of "Buy" and an average target price of GBX 13 ($0.17). 
LON RYA  opened at GBX 11.56 ($0.15) on Monday. The firm has a market capitalization of $125.96 million and a 
price-to-earnings ratio of 58.07. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 103.04, a quick ratio of 0.60 and a 
current ratio of 0.67. Ryanair has a one year low of GBX 8.05 ($0.11) and a one year high of GBX 16.97 ($0.22). 
The company's 50 day moving average price is GBX 10.98 and its 200 day moving average price is GBX 76.16.  
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

6 Rome youths positive on return from Porto Rotondo (17) And first COVID case tests positive in new Fiumicino 
screening
6 Rome youths positive on return from Porto Rotondo (17); And first COVID 
case tests positive in new Fiumicino screening
ANSA English Corporate Service
August 17, 2020 Monday 2:24 PM CET
©Copyright 2020 ANSA All Rights Reserved
Length: 212 words
Dateline: ROME 
Body
(ANSA) - 17 AGO - Six Roman youths have tested positive for the coronavirus after returning from the Sardinian 
resort of Porto Rotondo. They are two groups of three who attended a party there on August 8. Officials said a new 
cluster had been found at Porto Rotondo. Lazio's COVID crisis unit said the six had just tested positive. It added 
that new testing at Rome's Fiumicino Airport had detected a first positive case. It is a youth from Pescara in 
Abruzzo who flew back from Malta on a Ryanair flight. Contact tracing has been started, the unit said. "The young 
man has already been informed telephonically and placed in isolation", it said. A second case was then reported, a 
teenage Italian girl  back from the Greek island of Skiathos, via Athens. According to the latest figures Sunday, 
there were 472 new COVID cases across Italy in the previous 24 hours, 150 fewer than the previous daily tally in 
Italy. But the number of swabs was down too. Italy has been the second hardest hit European country after the UK. 
It has had over 35,000 COVID-related deaths. In all, it has had over 250,000 cases of the novel coronavirus. The 
government has ordered the re-closure of discotheques and the wearing of facemasks in 'movida' youth partying 
amid a spike among young people.

American Banking and Market News
August 17, 2020 Monday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 504 words
Body
Stock Analysts' updated eps estimates for Monday, August 17th: 
Aphria (NYSE:APHA) was upgraded by analysts at CIBC from a neutral rating to an outperform rating.  
Cimpress (NASDAQ:CMPR) was upgraded by analysts at Barrington Research from a market perform rating to an 
outperform rating.  
CNX Resources (NYSE:CNX) had its neutral rating reissued by analysts at MKM Partners. MKM Partners currently 
has a $11.00 price target on the stock.

rating. They currently have $39.00 price target on the stock, down from their previous price target of $41.00.

rating on the stock.

>>>ANSA/Coronavirus: 320 more cases, 4 more dead Mattarella says Italy shown moral and civic energies in 
crisis
>>>ANSA/Coronavirus: 320 more cases, 4 more dead; Mattarella says Italy 
shown moral and civic energies in crisis
ANSA English Corporate Service
August 17, 2020 Monday 6:35 PM CET
©Copyright 2020 ANSA All Rights Reserved
Length: 413 words
Dateline: ROME 
Body
(ANSA) - 17 AGO - Italy had 320 new coronavirus cases in the last 24 hours, 159 fewer than Sunday's rise of 479, 
the health ministry said Monday. But about 6,000 fewer swabs were taken in the last 24 hours, or some 30,666. The 
number of new dead was steady at four. The largest rises in infections were in Lazio (51), Veneto (46) and 
Lombardy (43). The total number of cases since the start of the pandemic has now risen to 254,235. The death toll 
is now 35,400. Molise and Basilicata are the only regions without new cases. 
Italy has shown its "moral and civic energies" during the coronavirus pandemic, President Sergio Mattarella said 
Monday.  "Our country has given proof, once again, of its moral and civic energies," Mattarella said in a message to 
the president of the foundation for the Friendship Meeting Between Peoples, Bernhard Scholz, devoted to the virus 
emergency. The annual Meeting of the Catholic militant movement Communion and Liberation will start in Rimini 
Tuesday. "Grasping change, which the European Union has been capable of in its response to the pandemic and in 
planning the restart, is today the premise for relaunching Italy," the head of State went on. "Only in European 
integration and solidarity can we build a fitting tomorrow for our children". Italy has been the second hardest hit 
European country after the UK. It has had over 35,000 COVID-related deaths. In all, it has had over 250,000 cases. 
The government has ordered the re-closure of discotheques amid a spike among young people. It has also made 
facemasks mandatory between six o'clock in the evening and six in the morning where young people gather for 
their 'movida' partying. Mattarella has consistently praised Italy's response to the pandemic. Six Roman youths 
have tested positive for the coronavirus after returning from the Sardinian resort of Porto Rotondo. They are two 
groups of three who attended a party there on August 8. Officials said a new cluster had been found at Porto 
Rotondo. Lazio's COVID crisis unit said the six had just tested positive. It added that new testing at Rome's 
Fiumicino Airport had detected a first positive case. It is a youth from Pescara in Abruzzo who flew back from Malta 
on a Ryanair flight. Contact tracing has been started, the unit said. "The young man has already been informed 
telephonically and placed in isolation", it said. A second case was then reported, a teenage Italian girl back from the 
Greek island of Skiathos, via Athens.
Load-Date: August 17, 2020

crisis

Ryanair to Reduce Flight Capacity by 20% in September, October; Shares Lose 5% Pre Bell
Ryanair to Reduce Flight Capacity by 20% in September, October; Shares 
Lose 5% Pre Bell
MT Newswires Live Briefs
August 17, 2020 Monday 9:19 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 110 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) reported in an Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it will reduce its flight 
capacity by 20% during September and October, saying forward bookings have "notably weakened" over the last 
10 days due to continuing uncertainty over rising Covid case rates in some EU countries.
Shares of Ryanair were down more than 4% in premarket trading.
A spokesperson for the airline said that proper testing at airports and effective tracing is the "only realistic and 
proportionate method of supervising safe intra-EU air travel while effectively limiting the spread of the Covid-19 
virus."

Ryanair Cuts Flights by 20% As Europe Sees Increased COVID-19 Cases Anew
Ryanair Cuts Flights by 20% As Europe Sees Increased COVID-19 Cases 
Anew
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
August 17, 2020 Monday 11:38 PM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 70 words
Body
 Following a 10-day decline in forward bookings due to rising COVID-19 rates in some countries in Europe, Ryanair 
(RYA.L) decided to reduce flight capacity for September and October by 20%.
The plan will be effected with less frequent flights to and from Spain, France and Sweden, instead of route closures.  
The stock closed Monday's trade nearly 6% in the red.

European Airlines Hit by UK Quarantine Rules for France, Netherlands
European Airlines Hit by UK Quarantine Rules for France, Netherlands
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
August 17, 2020 Monday 00:21
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 110 words
Body
 European airlines closed Friday in the red following Britain's decision to impose a 14-day quarantine on arrivals 
from France, the Netherlands and four other destinations.
The UK government advised against all but essential travel to the two countries, Monaco, Malta, Turks and Caicos 
Islands, and Aruba and required all passengers to self-isolate from Saturday due to their rising COVID-19 cases.
EasyJet (EZJ.L) fell 7% following the news, while Air France-KLM (AIRF.PA) tanked 6%. British Airways owner 
International Consolidated Airlines Group (IAG.L) and Ryanair Holdings (RYA.L) each dropped 5%.
Price (GBP): £570.80, Change: £-40.00, Percent Change: -6.55%

Ryanair cuts 20 per cent of autumn flights amid new quarantine rules
Ryanair cuts 20 per cent of autumn flights amid new quarantine rules
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 17, 2020 Monday 4:49 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 191 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair on Monday said it plans to cut 20 per cent of regular flights in September and October after 
several European nations reimposed Covid-19 quarantine rules for arrivals.
The reduction in flight capacity comes after forward bookings "notably weakened over the last 10 days, given 
continuing uncertainty over recent Covid case rates in some EU countries," the airline said.
Most of the cuts will be reductions in frequency rather than suspension of routes, it said.
They will focus on countries including Spain, France, Sweden and Ireland.
Ireland has imposed a "uniquely restrictive Green List" that requires visitors from most other EU nations, including 
those with lower recent infection rates, Ryanair said.
"Proper testing at airports, and effective tracing - as is being conducted in Germany and Italy - is the only realistic 
and proportionate method of supervising safe intra-EU air travel while effectively limiting the spread of the Covid-19 
virus," a spokesperson said.
Britain, one of Ryanair's biggest markets, has reimposed a 14-day self-isolation requirement for arrivals from 
countries including Spain, France and Sweden.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin Powell  Tel: +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 17, 2020
Ryanair cuts 20 per cent of autumn flights amid new quarantine rules
End of Document
Ryanair To Reduce Flight Capacity By 20% In Sept &Oct;.
Ryanair To Reduce Flight Capacity By 20% In Sept &Oct;.
RTT News (United States)
August 17, 2020 Monday
Copyright 2020 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2020 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 130 words
Byline: editorial@rttnews.com,  (RTT Staff Writer)
Body
       Low fares airline Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY, RYA.L) said Monday that it would reduce its flight capacity by 
20% during the months of September &October;, as weakness in forward bookings due to Covid restrictions in a 
number of European Union countries.
 The airline confirmed that most of those cuts would be frequency reductions rather than route closures. They will 
be heavily focused on those countries such as Spain, France and Sweden, where rising recent Covid case rates 
have led to increased travel restrictions, and Ireland which continues to impose a uniquely restrictive Green List, 
which imposes 14 day quarantines on visitors from most other EU countries such as Germany and the UK, which 
have lower Covid case rates over the last 14 days than Ireland.

6 Rome youths positive on return from Porto Rotondo (12)
6 Rome youths positive on return from Porto Rotondo (12)
ANSA English Corporate Service
August 17, 2020 Monday 12:39 PM CET
©Copyright 2020 ANSA All Rights Reserved
Length: 152 words
Dateline: ROME 
Body
(ANSA) - 17 AGO - Six Roman youths have tested positive for the coronavirus after returning from the Sardinian 
resort of Porto Rotondo. They are two groups of three who attended a party there on August 8. Officials said a new 
cluster had been found at Porto Rotondo. Lazio's COVID crisis unit said the six had just tested positive. It added 
that new testing at Rome's Fiumicino Airport had detected a first positive case. It is a youth from Pescara in 
Abruzzo who flew back from Malta on a Ryanair flight. Contact tracing has been started, the unit said. "The young 
man has already been informed telephonically and placed in isolation", it said. According to the latest figures 
Sunday, there were 472 new COVID cases across Italy in the previous 24 hours, 150 fewer than the previous daily 
tally in Italy. But the number of swabs was down too. Italy has been the second hardest hit European country after 
the UK.
Load-Date: August 17, 2020

Budget carrier Ryanair cuts flights as contagions increase
Budget carrier Ryanair cuts flights as contagions increase
Newstex Blogs 
MarketBeat
August 17, 2020 Monday 6:06 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 672 words
Body
Aug 17, 2020( MarketBeat: https://www.marketbeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Passengers board a Ryanair 
airplane, in Palermo, Italy, Saturday, Sept. 15, 2018. Italy's aviation authority, ENAC, has put RyanAir on notice that 
it has ''repeatedly violated'' rules aimed at curbing the spread of coronavirus, warning that the budget carrier risks 
suspension in Italy unless it complies. ENAC said in a statement Wednesday, Aug. 
5, 2020 that RyanAir had repeatedly disregarded rules, calling it ''behavior disrespectful of the health measures in 
Italy.'' They include requiring passengers to wear masks, restricting baggage on board to small items placed in 
plastic bags and preventing crowding at baggage pickup. (AP Photo/Andrew Medichini)LONDON (AP) — Ryanair, 
Europe's largest airline, plans to cut capacity by 20% in September and October as a surge in COVID-19 cases 
dents bookings. The low-cost carrier said Monday that most of the reductions would come from trimming the 
frequency of flights, rather than route closures. Ryanair said the cuts would be focused on flights serving countries 
such as Spain, France and Sweden, where a rise in coronavirus cases has triggered tighter travel restrictions. The 
airline said in a statement that the curbs were 'unavoidable given the recent weakness in forward bookings due to 
COVID restrictions in a number of EU countries.'' Affected passengers will receive emails advising them of their 
options. Dublin-based Ryanair also called on Ireland to ease restrictions on travel from countries where COVID-19 
infection rates are lower than in Ireland. Travelers from countries like Germany and the U.K. are required to 
quarantine for two weeks, even though Ireland has a higher infection rate. Meanwhile, British rival easyJet said it 
would move ahead with plans to close its bases at Stansted, Southend and Newcastle airports in England after 
consulting with unions. The airline said all flights to and from Southend would be cancelled beginning Sept. 1. 
EasyJet said it will continue to serve Stansted and Newcastle from other hubs, but some flights to and from the 
airports will be cancelled. EasyJet said in June that 1,900 jobs were at risk, but consultations continue and the 
overall number is likely to be lower. Of those at risk positions, some 670 pilot and crew jobs are located at the three 
bases whose closure was confirmed Monday.10 Best Tech Stocks to Buy After the Market's Historic Sell-
Off[1]Technology stocks are among the most volatile in the market. The allure of big gains comes with the risk of 
sharp downturns. When the market is trending upwards, these stocks have a tendency to lead the way. Conversely, 
when the market is selling off, tech stocks post some of the largest losses. And in the coronavirus crash tech stocks 
took their usual beating. But an interesting dynamic is happening. As stocks are trying to stage a comeback, many 
tech stocks are being left behind. Many of the leading tech stocks trade on the NASDAQ exchange. However, as 
the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) and S&#38;P 500 posted gains on March 25, the NASDAQ stayed down. 
And that's an opportunity for investors who know where to look. We've put together this presentation to give you ten 
technology stocks that look to be solid bets no matter which way the market moves. Some of the stocks you'll see 
Budget carrier Ryanair cuts flights as contagions increase
are companies that have a business model that is perfectly suited for today's social distancing environment. View 
the 
"10 
Best 
Tech 
Stocks 
to 
Buy 
After 
the 
Market's 
Historic 
Sell-Off"[2].

EasyJet /European airlines: capital pains
EasyJet/European airlines: capital pains
Financial Times (London, England)
August 15, 2020 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; Pg. 20
Length: 323 words
Body
Should you travel? Will you? Without a yes to both questions airlines such as easyJet cannot expect an 
improvement to their dire financial situation. Further UK quarantine measures, now extended to France, will make 
life harder. This explains easyJet's announcement yesterday to complete the second of two sale and leaseback 
transactions to raise a total of £608m.
Shareholders will be happy that easyJet did not dilute its stock further with another equity offering. But these latest 
leases add debt to its balance sheet, which reduces manoeuvrability on fares for the months ahead. Still, it is better 
placed than many of its peers.
Of nearly 90 sizeable airlines, only four earn an investment grade rating; easyJet is one of them. In Europe, Ryanair 
and Wizz Air have stronger financial positions when measured by the proportion of net debt to enterprise value. For 
Ryanair and Wizz Air this proportion is less than a fifth, according to estimates from brokers Davy. EasyJet's is 
higher at about a third, but much better than Air France-KLM at 78 per cent. That tells a story. Most European 
airlines will not be able to fight for market share using cheap fares. Debts must be serviced.
At least intra-European air travel volumes have improved. Flight traffic for easyJet and Ryanair jumped by more 
than half in the first two weeks of August compared with the previous two weeks, according to Eurocontrol.
The profitable north Atlantic route is up by a fraction of that. Bad news for flag carriers such as International Airline 
Group's British Airways. IAG is planning an emergency fundraising, which is expected to double its shares 
outstanding.
EasyJet /European airlines: capital pains
European airlines have turned off internal algorithms balancing fares with demand. Price elasticity is not there and 
customers do not respond to discounting. When they do, capacity will come back quickly. Profitability will remain a 
long-haul destination for this industry for some time to come.
Load-Date: August 14, 2020
End of Document
EasyJet /European airlines: capital pains
EasyJet/European airlines: capital pains
Financial Times (London, England)
August 15, 2020 Saturday

Body
Should you travel? Will you? Without a yes to both questions airlines such as easyJet cannot expect an 
improvement to their dire financial situation. Further UK quarantine measures, now extended to France, will make 
life harder. This explains easyJet's announcement yesterday to complete the second of two sale and leaseback 
transactions to raise a total of £608m.
Shareholders will be happy that easyJet did not dilute its stock further with another equity offering. But these latest 
leases add debt to its balance sheet, which reduces manoeuvrability on fares for the months ahead. Still, it is better 
placed than many of its peers.
Of nearly 90 sizeable airlines, only four earn an investment grade rating; easyJet is one of them. In Europe, Ryanair 
and Wizz Air have stronger financial positions when measured by the proportion of net debt to enterprise value. For 
Ryanair and Wizz Air this proportion is less than a fifth, according to estimates from brokers Davy. EasyJet's is 
higher at about a third, but much better than Air France-KLM at 78 per cent. That tells a story. Most European 
airlines will not be able to fight for market share using cheap fares. Debts must be serviced.
At least intra-European air travel volumes have improved. Flight traffic for easyJet and Ryanair jumped by more 
than half in the first two weeks of August compared with the previous two weeks, according to Eurocontrol.
The profitable north Atlantic route is up by a fraction of that. Bad news for flag carriers such as International Airline 
Group's British Airways. IAG is planning an emergency fundraising, which is expected to double its shares 
outstanding.
EasyJet /European airlines: capital pains
European airlines have turned off internal algorithms balancing fares with demand. Price elasticity is not there and 
customers do not respond to discounting. When they do, capacity will come back quickly. Profitability will remain a 
long-haul destination for this industry for some time to come.

Holidaymakers scramble back from France to beat quarantine Prices for ferries, trains and planes soar as 
people rush to snap up scarce tickets
Holidaymakers scramble back from France to beat quarantine; Prices for 
ferries, trains and planes soar as people rush to snap up scarce tickets
Financial Times (London, England)
August 15, 2020 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 3
Length: 801 words
Byline: ALICE HANCOCK; PHILIP GEORGIADIS; VICTOR MALLET
Body
British holidaymakers in France packed their bags yesterday to return to the UK before a newly imposed quarantine 
comes into effect, following a rise in coronavirus infections.
Prices soared as people rushed to snap up the few remaining tickets for flights, trains and ferries to cross the 
English Channel before the deadline of 4am this morning.
The exodus came after Downing Street announced on Thursday evening that travellers coming from France, the 
Netherlands, Monaco, Malta, the Turks and Caicos Islands and Aruba would have to self-isolate on arrival in the UK 
after sharp increases in Covid-19 cases in those countries. Data from France this week showed a 66 per cent surge 
in newly reported cases while the Netherlands was up 52 per cent.
France is the second most popular holiday destination for Britons after Spain, attracting 10.3m visits in 2019, 
according to the government. Some 160,000 UK tourists were estimated to be in France on Thursday and many of 
the 300,000 French citizens who live in the UK and were on holiday were also thought to have returned home.
The French government said it regretted the British move and would impose reciprocal measures on travellers 
arriving in France from the UK, although it did not specify when they would start.
Holidaymakers scramble back from France to beat quarantine Prices for ferries, trains and planes soar as 
people rush to snap up scarce tickets
Adele Armstrong, 37, who works in the City of London, said she had spent (EURO)1,000 changing flights to return 
from Brittany yesterday, rather than tomorrow as planned, as she and her daughter, partner and his two sons were 
due to go on another holiday to Scotland on Monday. They would have been forced to cancel if they had been 
quarantined.
"As soon as we heard the news, we went on the Ryanair website to change the flights ... I could see the seats 
disappearing before my eyes," said Ms Armstrong.
Amelie, an investment banker who had been working and holidaying in Poitiers with her husband, said that after 
hearing the news at midnight on Thursday, the only two available Eurotunnel bookings were at 7am or 11.30am 
yesterday.
As she and her husband both had to return to the UK for work compliance reasons, they were forced to leave their 
children, who were staying with grandparents in another part of France. "The motorway was full but every other car 
had a British plate," she said.
Veronique Michaud, owner of the three-star Hotel Champs Fleurs in the popular Alpine village of Morzine, said 
some British families had left in a frenzy yesterday morning.
Some travellers decided to leave their cars behind in France and fly back after all ferries and trains were booked. 
Others could not afford to return. "I suspected, as everyone did, that the UK government would impose a quarantine 
on France as it was on the cards since earlier this week, so I really should have booked an earlier flight, but I 
didn't," said Tim Crombie, a self-employed artist in Marseille. "I've tried to book a flight now but it would cost over 
(EURO)600."
Eurotunnel, which runs car-carrying services through the Channel tunnel, said it had laid on extra staff to handle the 
"huge amount" of inquiries. Travellers reported queues of more than 4,500 people on Eurotunnel's website.
Kasper Moos, head of UK routes for DFDS, which runs ferry services to France and Holland, said there was not 
enough space on their ships to cope with the demand. "We are running out of slots for the weekend," he said.
Grant Shapps, transport secretary, told the BBC people knew that there was a "significant risk" if they were 
travelling abroad. He warned people would be "breaking the law" if they failed to quarantine for 14 days on return.
Travellers arriving this week from Spain and Belgium, both of which had previously been removed from the "safe 
corridors" list, reported a mixed picture on quarantine enforcement. Most reported being told to fill in forms detailing 
where they would isolate, but added that checks on whether they had complied were lax or non-existent.
Officials in Paris said they expected the French requirements on British visitors to be the same as the "voluntary" 
self-quarantine applied the last time the UK imposed quarantines on people coming across the Channel.
The quarantine could also significantly affect companies that serve incoming tourists to the UK.
"France and the Netherlands are crucial markets for the UK. We had only recently heard reports that these two 
markets had started a slow recovery - this obviously ends that," said Joss Croft, chief executive of the trade body 
UKInbound.
"Normally solvent and sturdy businesses now face a bleak future."
France is the second-largest source market for tourists into the UK after the US, accounting for £1.5bn worth of 
spending, according to the UK Tourism Alliance.
Additional reporting by Laura Hughes, Robert Wright and Anna Gross
'I've tried to book a flight now but it would cost over (EURO)600'
Holidaymakers scramble back from France to beat quarantine Prices for ferries, trains and planes soar as 
people rush to snap up scarce tickets
Graphic
 
Exodus: traffic builds up as people queue for the cross-Channel ferry in Calais yesterday Olivier Matthys/AP
Load-Date: August 14, 2020
End of Document
British scramble to return from France; Coronavirus ; Holidaymakers struggle to secure tickets ahead of 
quarantine deadline
British scramble to return from France; Coronavirus ; Holidaymakers 
struggle to secure tickets ahead of quarantine deadline
Financial Times (London, England)
August 15, 2020 Saturday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 2
Length: 499 words
Byline: ALICE HANCOCK
Body
British holidaymakers in France packed their bags yesterday to return to the UK before a newly imposed quarantine 
came into effect, following a rise in coronavirus infections.
Prices soared as people rushed to snap up the remaining tickets for flights, trains and ferries before the deadline of 
4am this morning.
The exodus came after Downing Street announced on Thursday evening that travellers coming from France, the 
Netherlands, Monaco, Malta, the Turks and Caicos Islands, and Aruba would have to self-isolate on arrival in the 
UK after sharp increases in Covid-19 cases in those countries. Data from France this week showed a 66 per cent 
surge in newly reported cases, while the Netherlands was up 52 per cent.
France is the second most popular holiday destination for Britons after Spain, attracting 10.3m visits in 2019, 
according to the government. Some 160,000 UK tourists were estimated to be in France on Thursday and many of 
the 300,000 French citizens who live in the UK were also thought to have returned home on holiday.
The French government said it regretted the British move and would impose reciprocal measures on travellers 
arriving in France from the UK, although it did not specify when they would start.
British scramble to return from France; Coronavirus ; Holidaymakers struggle to secure tickets ahead of 
quarantine deadline
Adele Armstrong, 37, who works in the City of London, said she had spent (EURO)1,000 changing flights to return 
from Brittany on Friday, rather than Sunday as planned, because she and her daughter, partner and his two sons 
were due to go on another holiday to Scotland on Monday. They would have been forced to cancel if they had been 
quarantined.
"As soon as we heard the news, we went on the Ryanair website to change the flights ... I could see the seats 
disappearing before my eyes," said Ms Armstrong.
Some travellers decided to leave their cars behind in France and fly back after all ferries and trains were booked. 
Others could not afford to return.
Grant Shapps, UK transport secretary, said people knew that there was a "significant risk" if they were travelling 
abroad. He warned people would be "breaking the law" if they failed to quarantine for 14 days on return.
Travellers arriving this week from Spain and Belgium, both previously removed from the "safe corridors" list, 
reported a mixed picture on quarantine enforcement. Most told of being asked to fill in forms saying where they 
would isolate, but checks on whether they had complied were lax or non-existent.
Officials in Paris said they expected the French requirements on British visitors to be the same as the "voluntary" 
self-quarantine applied the last time the UK imposed quarantines on people coming across the Channel.
"We regret the British decision, which will lead to reciprocal measures," Clément Beaune, France's Europe minister, 
wrote on Twitter. Natacha Bouchart, mayor of Calais, called the British decision "another aggressive measure". 
Additional reporting by Laura Hughes, Robert Wright and Anna Gross
'The motorway was full but every other car had a British plate' Amelie, investment banker
Load-Date: August 14, 2020
End of Document

quarantine deadline

Ryanair 's (RYAAY) "Overweight" Rating Reiterated at Barclays
Ryanair's (RYAAY) "Overweight" Rating Reiterated at Barclays
American Banking and Market News
August 14, 2020 Friday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 701 words
Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY)'s stock had its "overweight" rating reissued by investment analysts at 
Barclays  in a report issued on Friday. 
Other research analysts also recently issued research reports about the stock. JPMorgan Chase & Co. raised 
shares of Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to an "overweight" rating in a research report on Monday, July 13th. UBS 
Group  restated a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Wednesday, May 20th. BidaskClub upgraded 
Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on Thursday. Zacks Investment Research  upgraded 
Ryanair from a "strong sell" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $68.00 price target for the company in a research note 
on Tuesday, May 26th. Finally, Credit Suisse Group  reaffirmed an "outperform" rating on shares of Ryanair in a 
research report on Tuesday, July 28th. Four research analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating, thirteen have 
given a buy rating and one  has issued  a strong buy rating to the company. The stock currently has an average 
rating of "Buy" and an average price target of $79.00. 
RYAAY stock  traded down $0.76 during midday trading on Friday, hitting $77.84. 6,721 shares of the company's 
stock were exchanged, compared to its average volume of 745,414. Ryanair has a one year low of $44.44 and a 
one year high of $96.79. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a current ratio of 
0.67. The company has a market cap of $18.55 billion, a PE ratio of 69.21 and a beta of 1.35. The stock's fifty day 
moving average price is $71.24 and its 200-day moving average price is $69.23.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its earnings results on Monday, July 27th. The transportation company 
reported ($0.94) earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping analysts' consensus estimates of ($1.15) by 
$0.21. Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%. The business had revenue of $137.83 
million during the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $138.60 million.  On average, analysts expect that  
Ryanair will post -3.74 EPS for the current year.  
Institutional investors have recently modified their holdings of the business. Smithfield Trust Co. raised its position 
in  Ryanair by 0.9% in the second quarter. Smithfield Trust Co. now owns 1,616 shares of the transportation 
company's stock worth $113,000 after acquiring an additional 15 shares during the period.  Private Advisor Group 
LLC grew its stake in  Ryanair by 1.6% in the 2nd quarter. Private Advisor Group LLC now owns 2,461 shares of 
the transportation company's stock valued at $275,000 after purchasing an additional 38 shares during the period.  
Pinnacle Associates Ltd. increased its position in shares of  Ryanair by 0.4% during the 2nd quarter. Pinnacle 
Associates Ltd. now owns 10,483 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $1,128,000 after 
purchasing an additional 43 shares during the last quarter.  Cavalier Investments LLC raised its stake in shares of  
Ryanair 's (RYAAY) "Overweight" Rating Reiterated at Barclays
Ryanair by 1.2% during the 4th quarter. Cavalier Investments LLC now owns 3,867 shares of the transportation 
company's stock worth $322,000 after purchasing an additional 44 shares during the period.  Finally, Baldwin 
Investment Management LLC boosted its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 0.5% in the 2nd quarter. Baldwin 
Investment Management LLC now owns 9,095 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $979,000 after 
buying an additional 44 shares during the last quarter. Institutional investors and hedge funds own  43.80% of the 
company's stock.  
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Fitch Expects European Airlines to Find Rough Road to Recovery
Fitch Expects European Airlines to Find Rough Road to Recovery
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
August 14, 2020 Friday 8:19 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 189 words
Body
 European airlines were hit the hardest by the COVID-19 pandemic during the first half of 2020 but are now on their 
way to a slow recovery as lockdown restrictions are lifted gradually, according to a Friday release by Fitch Ratings.
Fitch said European airlines hedged a larger share of expected fuel consumption than their peers abroad before the 
pandemic, although they managed to slash costs and preserve cash through job and salary cuts, dividend 
cancellations and reduced maintenance spending, among other things.
The rating agency expects demand for domestic, short-haul and intra-Europe flights to be stronger than 
intercontinental or long-haul flights, with demand for leisure and personal trips to outpace corporate demand.
Ryanair (RYA.L) and Wizz Air (WIZZ.L) are also expected to bounce back to pre-pandemic levels faster than 
international full-service carriers including International Consolidated Airlines Group (IAG.L), Deutsche Lufthansa 
(LHAG.DE) and Air France-KLM (AIRF.PA).
IAG shares tumbled 6%, Ryanair declined 5% and Wizz Air fell 1% on Friday afternoon.
Price (GBP): £11.52, Change: £11.52, Percent Change: -4.87%
Load-Date: August 14, 2020
End of Document
Post-Employment Restrictive Covenant Was Unenforceable Due to Being Too Wide, High Court of Ireland 
Rules
Post-Employment Restrictive Covenant Was Unenforceable Due to Being 
Too Wide, High Court of Ireland Rules
Newstex Blogs 
JD Supra
August 14, 2020 Friday 5:15 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 673 words
Byline: Ogletree, Deakins, Nash, Smoak & Stewart,
Body
Aug 14, 2020( JD Supra: http://www.jdsupra.com Delivered by Newstex)  [co-authors: Ailbhe Dennehy, Therese 
Chambers]*In a cautionary tale for employers, the High Court of Ireland held in Ryanair DAC v. Bellew[1] that 
although Ryanair DAC's post-employment noncompete clause was justified given the nature of the strategic role of 
chief operations officer (COO), the scope of this clause (which covered all airlines in any capacity) was too wide; 
therefore, the clause is void.BackgroundRyanair's former COO, Peter Bellew, held 'one of the most senior executive 
roles in Ryanair.' He entered into a post-employment noncompete clause with Ryanair in consideration for 
participation in Ryanair's share option scheme. The noncompete clause provided that Bellew would not be 
'employed, engaged, concerned or interested in any capacity in any business wholly or partly in competition with 
the Company for air passenger services in any market' for 12 months following his departure.Bellew resigned from 
Ryanair in July 2019 and was due to join EasyJet Switzerland SA (easyJet) as COO on January 1, 2020. Ryanair 
commenced injunctive proceedings to prevent Bellew from joining easyJet until the noncompete period had 
elapsed.Ryanair asserted that Bellew was privy to 'confidential material and sensitive commercial and operational 
information,' and that Ryanair would be 'exposed to irremediable and unquantifiable loss and damage' if Bellew 
were to commence employment with easyJet. 
Bellew argued that the restraint Ryanair sought to impose was 'wholly unnecessary, unreasonable and 
unwarranted.'The High Court's FindingsAddressing the crucial issue of the enforceability of the restraint, the court 
confirmed that any restraint on a person working is 'by definition a restraint of trade,' and that such a restraint is void 
and unenforceable unless it is reasonable as between the parties and it is consistent with the public interest.The 
court ultimately agreed that the 'nature and extent of the confidential information that would inevitably come to the 
knowledge of Mr. Bellew in the course of his employment' justified a post-employment restraint. Of some relief to 
employers, the court stated that it had 'no difficulty with the time constraint' of 12 months. However, the court said 
that it was 'vexed' as to whether the restraint went 'further than is necessary for the legitimate protection of 
Ryanair's interest.'Ryanair argued that while it was in competition with all airlines, the main competition it faced was 
not from legacy airlines (i.e., high-cost airlines), but from low-cost carriers, of which easyJet was its 'most 
immediate rival.' However, from the court's perspective, the restraint applied to any business in competition with 
Ryanair for air services, including the legacy airlines. It also applied to any job that Bellew might take with a 
Post-Employment Restrictive Covenant Was Unenforceable Due to Being Too Wide, High Court of Ireland 
Rules
competitor, not just a similar role.Fatally, the court found that the restrictive covenant was too wide and 
consequently 'void and unenforceable as an unjustified restraint of trade.'CommentSo what can employers do to 
bolster the enforceability of their restrictive covenants?There is a delicate balance to be struck between a 
reasonable and justifiable restrictive covenant and a restraint designed simply to 'hobble' an employee in the 
'legitimate pursuit of his career.'In an effort to strike this balance, employers may want to be wary of overreliance on 
boilerplate restrictive covenants. It is vital that restrictions are tailored to each employee, taking into account his or 
her seniority and level of access to confidential information, and go no further than absolutely necessary to protect 
the employer's legitimate interests. Employers may also want to review their restrictive covenants often to reflect 
the 
changing 
life 
cycle 
of 
an 
employee 
(e.g., 
following 
a 
promotion).*William 
Fry

7c2b81458e80/%5b2019%5d_IEHC_907_Ryanair%20DAC%20v.%20Bellew_P_6239_2019.pdf/pdf

European stocks tumble after the UK adds six more countries to its COVID-19 travel quarantine list
European stocks tumble after the UK adds six more countries to its COVID-
19 travel quarantine list
Newstex Blogs 
The Business Insider
August 14, 2020 Friday 11:20 AM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1507 words
Byline: Shalini Nagarajan
Body
Aug 14, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  European stocks fell 
on Friday as the UK added six more countries to its 14-day COVID-19 quarantine list.The UK's benchmark FTSE 
100 fell 1.9% and the Euro Stoxx 50 dropped 1.6% in early European trading.The decision, which comes into effect 
Saturday, implies that travellers arriving in the UK from countries including France and the Netherlands have a 
window of a little over 30 hours to return home to avoid restrictions.Data from Eurostat shows Eurozone GDP 
shrank 12% for the second quarter, its sharpest decline since records began in 1995.Visit Business Insider's 
homepage for more stories[1]. European stocks tumbled on Friday after the UK added six more countries[2] to its 
COVID-19 travel quarantine list, which weighed heavily on airline and travel stocks.The decision means that 
travellers arriving in the UK from France, Netherlands, Malta, Monaco, Aruba, and the Turks and Caicos Islands will 
be required to self-isolate for 14 days. Anyone breaking the rules will be liable for a fine.London's benchmark FTSE 
100 fell 1.9%, on course for its biggest one-day fall this month, while the Euro Stoxx 50 fell 1.6%, also set for its 
largest one-day decline this month.Weighing heavily on the European travel industry, the UK's latest restrictions 
"contributed to a moody open for the continent's markets" and "the FTSE continued to unwind its hard-to-justify 
post-recession reveal gains," said Connor Campbell, a financial analyst at SpreadEx.UK-based airlines and 
European tour operators saw sharp drops, as shares in EasyJet[3] and British Airways parent IAG[4] fell 7%, while 
budget airline Ryanair[5] and German travel company Tui[6] fell about 5%. Read more:Fred Liu's Hayden Capital 
has returned more than 100% in 2020. He breaks down the simple strategy he used to pinpoint 2 stocks that grew 
10 times within just a few years.[7]The UK's decision to impose this new directive was enacted to "keep infection 
rates down[8]," according to Britain's transport secretary Grant Shapps.As of last week, an estimated 450,000 
holidaymakers were still in France, according to the Telegraph newspaper[9], with many thousands more holidays 
booked in the coming weeks, implying that any quarantine restrictions would represent a greater logistical challenge 
than in any other country.The mandate comes after France, a major holiday destination for travellers from the UK, 
added over 2,524 new coronavirus cases[10] in 24 hours — the highest one-day rise since its lockdown lifted in 
May.Spain, another popular destination, was removed from Britain's "travel corridor"[11] last month, meaning any 
UK-based visitors must also quarantine for 14 days upon their return.Separately, oil prices fell on Friday with 
benchmark Brent[12] crude down 0.4% at $44 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate[13] down 0.6% at $42.On 
Thursday, the Internal Energy Agency downgraded[14] its global oil demand forecast for both 2020 and 2021 on 
expectations of weakness in the aviation sector, as the coronavirus pandemic continues to hamper air

travel.Separate data[15] from the EU statistics agency showed GDP growth for the second quarter in the euro zone 
plunged by the sharpest level since records began in 1995, falling 12%, and by 11.7% quarter-on-quarter.Euro zone 
unemployment came in at -2.8%, versus expectations for -1.7%.Read more:Goldman Sachs explains the biggest

and Japan's Nikkei[19] up 0.2%.European equities fell, with Germany's DAX[20] down 1.2%, Britain's FTSE 100[21] 
down 1.9%, and the Euro Stoxx 50[22] down 1.6%.US stocks are set to open lower.

Amsterdam, Brussels airports introduce mobile coronavirus testing
Amsterdam, Brussels airports introduce mobile coronavirus testing
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 13, 2020 Thursday 4:20 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 378 words
Byline: Leonie Kijewski in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The main airports in Amsterdam and Brussels are rolling out mobile coronavirus testing points for passengers in an 
effort to curb the pandemic.
In Amsterdam, passengers on some flights returning from countries deemed high risk in terms of infections can be 
tested for free as of Thursday.
This includes passengers without symptoms, the public health authority announced. The test results are to be 
available within 48 hours.
Testing capacity is currently limited at the Dutch airport, but the health authority plans to offer up to 600 tests a day 
as soon as possible, it said in a press release.
People are not required to undergo testing on returning to the Netherlands for legal reasons, the health authority 
said.
In a similar approach, Brussels Airport in neighbouring Belgium announced on Thursday that it would roll out mobile 
testing in early September.
Passengers returning from countries or areas designated as belonging to a red zone - meaning they are deemed 
high risk by the Belgian authorities - can be tested at the airport.
At the mobile testing stations, "passengers returning from a red zone can be tested immediately upon arrival at 
Brussels Airport," Arnaud Feist, who heads Brussels Airport Company, said in a press release.
Unlike in the Netherlands, people returning to Belgium from high-risk areas are required to undergo testing.
Amsterdam, Brussels airports introduce mobile coronavirus testing
Passengers returning from high-risk areas are to be charged 47 euros (56 dollars) for the virus test.
Departing passengers can also be tested, but would pay higher fees. Those undergoing standard testing, with the 
results available some nine hours later, would pay 67 euros. Faster testing is also to be offered, with the results 
available in three hours, for 135 euros.
Charleroi Airport, Brussels' second airport with flights mainly offered by Ryanair and Wizzair, has not announced 
similar measures.
More and more airports are offering mobile testing for the virus. While some places such as Singapore introduced 
testing for passengers with symptoms as early as March, Germany started offering tests free of charge for 
passengers on Saturday.
While international flights ground to a halt in March and April, Europe's summer holiday season has seen an 
increase in air travel - and a corresponding rise in the number of cases.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams Tel: +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 13, 2020
End of Document
Brussels Airport to introduce mobile coronavirus testing
Brussels Airport to introduce mobile coronavirus testing
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 13, 2020 Thursday 2:25 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 154 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Brussels Airport will introduce mobile labs for coronavirus tests for passengers at the beginning of September, it 
announced on Thursday.
Passengers returning from a red zone - countries or regions that Belgium deems to carry a high risk for coronavirus 
infections - will be able to get tested at the airport.
"There passengers returning from a red zone can be tested immediately upon arrival at Brussels Airport," Arnaud 
Feist, the boss of Brussels Airport Company, said in a press release.
The test for arriving passengers that must be tested will cost about 47 euros (56 dollars).
Departing passengers can also get tested, albeit at a higher cost: 67 euros for a standard test for which results will 
be available within about 9 hours, or 135 euros for a rapid test with results being available within 3 hours.
Charleroi Airport, Brussels second airport that caters mainly to Ryanair and Wizzair, has not announced similar 
measures.

Profund Advisors LLC Buys 1,004 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Profund Advisors LLC Buys 1,004 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
Newstex Blogs 
Watchlist News
August 12, 2020 Wednesday 12:30 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1024 words
Body
Aug 12, 2020( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Profund Advisors LLC Buys 
1,004 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) August 12th, 2020 - Comments Off on Profund Advisors 
LLC Buys 1,004 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) - Filed Under[1] - by Micah Haroldson[2]   
Profund Advisors LLC raised its stake in Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 22.2% in the second quarter, 
according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The fund owned 5,521 
shares of the transportation company's stock after acquiring an additional 1,004 shares during the quarter. Profund 
Advisors LLC's holdings in Ryanair were worth $366,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.  Other hedge funds also 
recently bought and sold shares of the company. 
Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Holdings Inc. lifted its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 178.6% in the second quarter. 
Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Holdings Inc. now owns 52,627 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$3,491,000 after acquiring an additional 33,738 shares during the last quarter. Harbor Investment Advisory LLC 
raised its holdings in Ryanair by 11.2% in the 2nd quarter. Harbor Investment Advisory LLC now owns 1,904 shares 
of the transportation company's stock valued at $126,000 after buying an additional 191 shares during the last 
quarter. State Street Corp raised its holdings in Ryanair by 21.9% in the 1st quarter. State Street Corp now owns 
88,058 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $4,675,000 after buying an additional 15,821 shares 
during the last quarter. Dynamic Technology Lab Private Ltd bought a new position in Ryanair in the 1st quarter 
valued at approximately $212,000. Finally, Franklin Resources Inc. bought a new position in Ryanair in the 1st 
quarter valued at approximately $6,333,000. 43.80% of the stock is owned by hedge funds and other institutional 
investors.  A number of research analysts recently issued reports on RYAAY shares. BidaskClub upgraded shares 
of Ryanair from a 'sell' rating to a 'hold' rating in a report on Tuesday, July 21st. Zacks Investment Research[3] 
upgraded shares of Ryanair from a 'strong sell' rating to a 'buy' rating and set a $68.00 price objective for the

August 12, 2020 Wednesday

Body
Ryanair logo Hosking Partners LLP reduced its holdings in  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 5.5% 
during the 2nd quarter, according to the company in its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities and 
Exchange Commission. The firm owned 498,558 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 28,792 
shares during the period. Ryanair comprises  1.0% of Hosking Partners LLP's holdings, making the stock its 26th 
largest position. Hosking Partners LLP owned about 0.22% of Ryanair worth $33,074,000 as of its most recent SEC 
filing.  
A number of other institutional investors and hedge funds have also modified their holdings of the business. Harbor 
Investment Advisory LLC boosted its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 11.2% in the second quarter. Harbor 
Investment Advisory LLC now owns 1,904 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $126,000 after 
acquiring an additional 191 shares during the last quarter.  Ladenburg Thalmann Financial Services Inc. boosted its 
stake in shares of  Ryanair by 8.7% in the fourth quarter. Ladenburg Thalmann Financial Services Inc. now owns 
5,035 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $435,000 after acquiring an additional 405 shares during 
the last quarter.  Crossmark Global Holdings Inc. boosted its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 5.2% in the first quarter. 
Crossmark Global Holdings Inc. now owns 9,111 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $484,000 after 
acquiring an additional 450 shares during the last quarter.  Northwestern Mutual Investment Management Company 
LLC boosted its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 3.7% in the first quarter. Northwestern Mutual Investment 
Management Company LLC now owns 16,250 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $863,000 after 
acquiring an additional 579 shares during the last quarter.  Finally, Comerica Bank boosted its stake in shares of  
Ryanair by 6.1% in the second quarter. Comerica Bank now owns 13,032 shares of the transportation company's 
stock worth $941,000 after acquiring an additional 751 shares during the last quarter. 43.80% of the stock is 
currently owned by institutional investors.  
A number of equities analysts recently commented on the company. BidaskClub upgraded Ryanair from a "sell" 
rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Tuesday, July 21st. UBS Group  reiterated a "buy" rating on shares 
of Ryanair in a research report on Wednesday, May 20th. Zacks Investment Research  upgraded Ryanair from a 
"strong sell" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $68.00 price objective on the stock in a research report on Tuesday, 
May 26th. Morgan Stanley  reiterated an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Tuesday, 
July 28th. Finally, Credit Suisse Group  reiterated an "outperform" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report 
on Tuesday, July 28th. Five research analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating, twelve have assigned  a buy 
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Shares Sold by Hosking Partners LLP
rating and one  has assigned  a strong buy rating to the company. Ryanair presently has an average rating of "Buy" 
and a consensus price target of $79.00. 
Shares of RYAAY stock  traded up $0.54 on Wednesday, hitting $82.33. The stock had a trading volume of 7,064 
shares, compared to its average volume of 750,881. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a current ratio 
of 0.67 and a quick ratio of 0.67. The firm has a market capitalization of $18.55 billion, a P/E ratio of 72.38 and a 
beta of 1.35. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1 year low of $44.44 and a 1 year high of $96.79. The company's 50 day 
moving average price is $70.80 and its 200-day moving average price is $69.33.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 27th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.94) earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating the Thomson Reuters' consensus 
estimate of ($1.15) by $0.21. The firm had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to the consensus 
estimate of $138.60 million. Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%.  On average, 
equities analysts forecast that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post -3.74 EPS for the current year.  
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Ryanair logo M&T Bank Corp decreased its holdings in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 
72.8% in the 2nd quarter, according to the company in its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities & 
Exchange Commission. The fund owned 4,735 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 12,682 
shares during the quarter. M&T Bank Corp's holdings in Ryanair were worth $315,000 at the end of the most recent 
quarter.

average is $69.33. The firm has a market capitalization of $18.55 billion, a PE ratio of 72.38 and a beta of 1.35. The 
company has a current ratio of 0.67, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60.

company reported ($0.94) EPS for the quarter, topping the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of ($1.15) by 
$0.21. The business had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $138.60 
million. Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%.  On average, sell-side analysts predict

shares last traded at $11.86, with a volume of 678,213 shares changing hands.

of Ryanair in a report on Friday, May 22nd. Morgan Stanley  reaffirmed a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a

market capitalization of $136.86 million and a PE ratio of 21.68.  
About Ryanair (LON:RYA ) 
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

on Ryanair from $68.00 to $90.00 and gave the company a "strong-buy" rating in a report on Thursday, July 30th.

Zacks Investment Research[2] upgraded Ryanair from a "strong sell" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $68.00 price 
target on the stock in a research note on Tuesday, May 26th. Five research analysts have rated the stock with a 
hold rating, twelve have given a buy rating and one has given a strong buy rating to the company's stock. The stock 
presently has an average rating of "Buy" and a consensus target price of $79.00.Ryanair ProfileRyanair Holdings

Ryanair , Virgin Atlantic and Tui 'breaching flight refund promises'
Ryanair, Virgin Atlantic and Tui 'breaching flight refund promises'
Newstex Blogs 
The Week UK
August 12, 2020 Wednesday 9:51 AM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 665 words
Byline: Mike
Body
Aug 12, 2020( The Week UK: http://www.theweek.co.uk Delivered by Newstex)  Description New probe finds that 
the three airlines are failing to keep promise to aviation watchdog to process passenger claims more quickly  
Credits Paul Ellis/AFP via Getty Images Alt Text Airline passenger refunds  New probe finds that the three airlines 
are failing to keep promise to aviation watchdog to process passenger claims more quickly One-Minute Read[1] 
Mike Starling[2] Wednesday, August 12, 2020 - 10:41am Three major airlines are breaching pledges to the Civil 
Aviation Authority (CAA) to refund passengers for flights cancelled as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, 
according to a Which? investigation. In areport[3]in July,the industry regulator named and shamed Ryanair, Virgin 
Atlantic and Tui for 'not processing refund requests[4]sufficiently quickly' and 'having a sizeable backlog of refund 
requests'. But after 'brazenly breaking the law by forcing passengers to wait up to four months for their money 
back', the three carriers have failed to keep their promises to speed up the return of 'hundreds of thousands of 
pounds in refunds', says theDaily Mail[5].CAA 'needs more powers'The airlines promised the CAA that refunds 
would be issued within agreed timeframes, butWhich?
[6]found that claims are still taking months to process. The consumer group's travel editor, Rory Boland, is now 
calling on the government to give the industry watchdog 'the tools it needs to hold airlines to account, or risk 
consumer trust in the travel industry being damaged beyond repair'. 'Time after time, Which? has exposed airlines 
breaking the law on refunds for cancelled flights due to the pandemic and treating their passengers unfairly, and 
we're concerned that they now feel empowered to do as they please without fear of punishment,' Boland said. See 
related Holiday coronavirus cancellations: what are your rights on refunds?[7] Travel corridors: full list of quarantine-
free countries[8] Responding to the Which? probe findings, CAA spokespersonAndrew McConnell said: 'We will 
review any supplementary evidence that Which? wish to provide to us beyond the 12,000 cases previously 
submitted during our review of airline refund policies and performance during the Covid-19 pandemic. 'While our 
initial review has concluded, we have been clear that we will continue to monitor performance closely and should 
any airline fall short of the commitments they have made to us, we will take further action as required.'What have 
the airlines said?Ryanair told the BBC[9]that it had issued 670m in refunds and had cleared more than 90% of its 
claims backlog.Meanwhile, Virgin said it was 'very sorry'that a 'small number' of customers had to wait more than 
120 days for a refund. And'Tui said it now issued refunds automatically and normally processed cash refunds within 
two 
weeks' 
, 
the 
broadcaster 
reports.

Ryanair eyes Russia in the Winter 2020/21 season
Ryanair eyes Russia in the Winter 2020/21 season
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
August 11, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 344 words
Body
eiemr
Ryanair (FR, Dublin Int'l) is gearing up to enter Russia, having secured traffic rights from the Italian civil aviation 
authority (Ente Nazionale per L'aviazione Civile - ENAC) for 4x weekly flights from Italy to St. Petersburg starting 
during the Winter 2020/21 season. The relevant decision by ENAC's Air Transport Development and Licensing 
Department did not specify the Italian airports of origin. 
Ryanair has yet to formally confirm the plans. The Irish LCC does not currently serve Russia. Its rival Wizz Air (W6, 
Budapest) has recently announced plans to launch its first Russian base at St. Petersburg airport starting in 
September 2020. Meanwhile, easyJet Europe (EC, Vienna), which stopped flying to Russia in 2015, is planning to 
enter Ukraine, having also secured 12x weekly frequencies from ENAC, all of which are due to launch by the end of 
the current summer season. Wizz Air (W6, Budapest) also received traffic rights for 96x weekly flights from Italy to 
Ukraine, also due to launch in the current season, while Ryanair was authorised to operate 56x weekly flights from 
Italy to Ukraine, of which half has to launch by the end of the Summer 2020 season and the remainder in the 
upcoming winter season. According to the ch-aviation schedules module, Ryanair and Wizz Air already operate 
Italy-Ukraine routes (the former's flights are operated by its subsidiary Malta Air). easyJet Europe or its parent 
easyJet (U2, London Luton) do not currently serve Ukraine at all. Scheduled flights between these two countries are 
also operated by numerous Ukrainian airlines, namely Ukraine International Airlines, SkyUp Airlines, Windrose 
Airlines, and Jonika Airlines. Alitalia also flies to Kyiv Igor Sikorsky.
AirGuide and Pyramid Media connects you to an affluent, influential group of business and leisure travelers from 
across 
the 
globe 
with

and

Destinations 
Magazine.
